div0.head: Χ

div1.head: χάζω
div1.sense: to cause to retire, the Act. only in Epic redupl. aor2 κέκαδον, fut. κεκαδήσω:— to force to retire from, deprive of, τοὺς ψυχῆς κεκαδών Il.; ἀριστῆας κεκαδήσει θυμοῦ καὶ ψυχῆς Od.
Mid. to give way, draw or shrink back, retire, Il.

c. gen. to draw back or retire from, χάζεσθε μάχης Il., etc.; so, χ. ἐκ βελέων, ὑπʼ ἔγχεος Il.; οὐδὲ δὴν χάζετο ἀνδρός nor in truth was he (or it, the stone) far from the man, i. e. nearly hit him, Il.

div1.head: χάϊος
div1.sense: genuine, true, good, Lacon. word in Ar.; so, χαός, όν, χαοὶ οἱ ἐπάνωθεν the good men of olden time, Theocr.

div1.head: χαιρηδών
div1.sense: delectation, Com. word in Ar., formed after ἀλγηδών.

div1.head: χαίρω
div1.sense: to rejoice, be glad, be delighted Hom., etc.; χ. θυμῶι or ἐν θυμῶι, χ. φρεσὶν ἧισι Hom.:—c. dat. rei, to rejoice at, be delighted with, take delight in a thing, Hom., etc.; so, χαίρειν ἐπί τινι Soph., Xen.:— c. part., χαίρω τὸν μῦθον ἀκούσας I rejoice at having heard, Il.; χαίρεις ὁρῶν Eur.; χαίρω φειδόμενος Ar.;— with part. pres. χαίρω sometimes takes the sense of φιλέω, to be wont to do, χαίρουσι χρεώμενοι Hdt., etc.

with negat., οὐ χαιρήσεις thou wilt or shalt not rejoice, i. e. thou shalt not go unpunished, shalt repent it, Ar.; so in Hom., οὐδέ τινʼ οἴω Τρώων χαιρήσειν Il.; so with an interrog., σὺ χαιρήσειν νομίζεις; Plut.: v. inf. IV. 2
imperat. χαῖρε, dual χαίρετον, pl. χαίρετε, is a common form of greeting,
at meeting, hail, welcome, Lat. salve, Hom., Attic; κῆρυξ Ἀχαιῶν, χαῖρε . . Answ. χαίρω I accept the greeting, Aesch.
at taking leave and parting, fare-thee-well, farewell, good-bye, Lat. vale, Od., Attic

the notion of taking leave or parting appears also in the 3 pers. sg. χαιρέτω, have done with it, away with it, εἴτε ἐγένετο ἄνθρωπος εἴτε ἐστι δαίμων, χαιρέτω as to the question whether he was born a man or is a divinity, let it be put aside, Hdt.; χαιρέτω βουλεύματα Eur.
part. χαίρων, glad, joyful, delighted, Hom.; so, κεχαρηκώς Hdt.

joined with another Verb, in the sense of safe, with impunity, Lat. impune, χαίρων ἀπαλλάττει Hdt.; with a negat., οὐ χαίρων, Lat. haud impune, to oneʼs cost, οὐ χαίροντες ἐμὲ γέλωτα θήσεσθε Hdt.; οὔ τι χαίρων ἐρεῖς Soph.: v. supr. II.
in same sense as imperat. (supr. III.), σὺ δέ μοι χαίρων ἀφίκοιο mayʼst thou fare well and arrive, Od.; ἀλλʼ ἑρπέτω χαίρουσα let her go with a benison, Soph.

the inf. is used to refer to the word χαῖρε as used in greeting (supr. III. 1), χαίρειν δὲ τὸν κήρυκα προὐννέπω I bid the herald welcome, Soph.:—at the beginning of letters the inf. stood alone (λέγει or κελεύει being omitted, as in Lat. S. = salutem, for S. D. = salutem dicit), Κῦρος Κυαξάρηι χαίρειν Xen.

in bad sense, like χαιρέτω, ἐᾶν χαίρειν τινά or τι to dismiss from oneʼs mind, put away from one, renounce, Hdt., Ar., etc.; πολλὰ χ. κελεύειν τινά Ar.; so c. dat. pers., πολλὰ χαίρειν ξυμφοραῖς καταξιῶ Aesch.; φράσαι χαίρειν Ἀθηναίοισι Ar.

div1.head: χαιτήεις
div1.sense: with long flowing hair, Pind., Anth.

div1.head: χαίτη
div1.sense: long, flowing hair, Hom.; and in pl. of a single person, χαίτας πεξαμένη Il.
of a horseʼs mane, Il.; of a lionʼs mane, Lat. juba, Eur., Ar.
metaph. of trees, leaves, foliage, in pl., Theocr.

div1.head: χαίτωμα
div1.sense: a plume, Aesch.

div1.head: χάλαζα
div1.sense: hail, Lat. grando, Il.; pl. a hailshower, hailstorm, Xen., Plat.; χ. στρογγύλαι hailstones, Ar.:—metaph. any pelting shower, ὀμβρία χ. Soph.; χ. αἵματος Pind.

div1.head: χαλαζάω
div1.sense: to hail, Luc.
to have pimples or tubercles, Ar.

div1.head: χαλαζεπής
div1.sense: hurling abuse as thick as hail, Anth.

div1.head: χαλαζήεις
div1.sense: like hail, φόνος χ. murder thick as hail, Pind.

div1.head: χαλαρός
div1.sense: slack, loose, Thuc., Xen.;x. κοτυληδών a loose, supple joint, Ar.; χ. ἁρμονίαι loose, languid, effeminate music, Plat.

div1.head: χαλαρότης
div1.sense: slackness, looseness, Xen.

div1.head: χάλασις
div1.sense: a slackening, loosening, Plat.

div1.head: χάλασμα
div1.sense: a slackened condition: a gap in the line of battle, σύμμετρον ἔχειν χ. to be placed at fitting intervals, Plut.

div1.head: Χαλαστραῖος
div1.sense: of or from Chalastra on the Thermaic gulf:— τὸ Χαλαστραῖον (sc. νίτρον) , soda, found there, and used for purposes of cleansing, Plat.

div1.head: χαλάω
div1.sense: trans. to slacken, loosen, χ. βιόν, τόξα to unstring the bow, h. Hom., Plat.: metaph., χ. τὴν ὀργήν Ar.
to let down, let sink, fall or droop, πτέρυγα χαλάξαις Pind.; χαλάσας τὸ μέτωπον having unbent the brow, Ar.; δίκτυα χ. N.T.
to let loose, loose, release, Aesch.:—absol. to let go, slacken oneʼs hold, Aesch.
ἡνίας χ. to slack the reins, Plat.
κλῇθρα or κλῇδας χ. to loose the bars or bolts, i. e. undo or open the door, Soph., Eur.; also, πύλας μοχλοῖς χαλᾶτε Aesch.
to loosen or undo things drawn tightly together, Soph., Eur.:—Pass., πρὶν ἂν χαλασθῇ δεσμά Aesch.
intr. to become slack or loose, Eur.; πύλαι χαλῶσι the gates stand open, Xen.:—metaph., c. gen., to have a remission of, μανιῶν, κακῶν Aesch.; τῆς ὀργῆς Ar.
c. dat., χ. τινί to yield to any one, to be indulgent to him, Aesch.
absol. to remit, to grow slack, Plat.

div1.head: Χαλδαῖος
div1.sense: a Chaldaean, Hdt., etc.
an astrologer, caster of nativities, Cic., etc.

div1.head: χαλεπαίνω
div1.sense: to be severe, sore, grievous, like Lat. ingravescere, of storms, Hom.

mostly of persons, to be violent, sorely angry, savage, Il., Attic:—c. dat. to be angry with others, Hom., etc.; so, χ. ἐπί τινι Od.; πρός τινα Xen.:—also c. dat. pers. et rei, χ. τινὶ τοῖς εἰρημένοις to be angry with him for his words, Xen.
to provoke to anger, Arist.:—Pass. to be provoked, Xen.
in Pass. also, to be treated harshly, Plat.

div1.head: χαλεπός
div1.sense: Lat. difficilis:

hard to bear, painful, sore, grievous, Hom., Hdt., Attic; θώρακες δύσφοροι καὶ χ., of ill-fitting cuirasses, Xen.: τὸ χαλεπὸν τοῦ πνεύματος the severity of the wind, Xen.; τὰ χαλεπά hardships, sufferings, Xen.

hard to do or deal with, difficult, Ar., Thuc., etc.; χαλεπὸν ὁ βίος life is a hard thing, Xen.:—c. inf., χαλεπή τοι ἐγὼ ἀντιφέρεσθαι χαλεπόν ἐστί μοι ἀντιφέρεσθαί σοι, Il.; so, χαλεπὸν δέ τʼ ὀρύσσειν τὸ μῶλυ Od.; χ. προσπολεμεῖν ὁ βασιλεύς Isocr.:— χαλεπόν ἐστι, c. inf., ʼtis hard, difficult to do, Hom.
dangerous, Od., Thuc.
of ground, difficult, rugged, Thuc., Xen.; χ. χωρίον a place difficult to take, Xen.

of persons, hard to deal with, harsh, severe, stern, strict, Od.; χαλεπώτερος a more bitter enemy, Thuc.; χαλεπώτατοι most difficult to deal with, most dangerous or troublesome, Thuc.:—of judges, severe, Hdt., Dem.
of savage animals, Xen.
ill-tempered, angry, testy, Ar.; ὀργὴν χαλεπός Hdt.

adv. χαλεπῶς, hardly, with difficulty, Lat. aegre, διαγνῶναι χ. ἦν ἄνδρα ἕκαστον ʼtwas difficult to distinguish, Il.; χ. εὑρίσκειν, opp. to ῥᾳδίως μανθάνειν, Isocr.; οὐ or μὴ χαλ. without much ado, Thuc.
hardly, scarcely, δοκέω χ. ἂν Ἕλληνας Πέρσῃσι μάχεσθαι Hdt.; χ. ἂν πείσαιμι Plat.
χ. ἔχει χαλεπόν ἐστι, Thuc., Xen.
painfully, miserably, χαλεπώτερον, -ώτατα ζῆν Plat.; ἐν τοῖς χαλεπώτατα διάγειν to live in the utmost misery, Thuc.

of persons, harshly, severely, Eur., Thuc., etc.:— χ. φέρειν τι, like Lat. aegre ferre, Thuc.: often in the phrase χ. ἔχειν, to be angry, Xen.; χ. ἔχειν τινὶ ἐπί τινι to be angry with a person for a thing, Dem.; χ. διακεῖσθαι πρός τινα Plat.
χ. ἔχειν, also, = Lat. male se habere, Plat.

div1.head: χαλεπότης
div1.sense: difficulty, ruggedness, Thuc.
of persons, difficulty, harshness, rigour, severity, Thuc., etc.
ill-temper, vice, of a horse, Xen.

div1.head: χαλέπτω
div1.sense: to oppress, depress, crush, Od., Hes.
Pass., χαλεφθείς τινι enraged at one, Theogn.
intr. to be angry, vexed at, τινί Bion.

div1.head: χαλίκρητος
div1.sense: unmixed, Archil.

div1.head: χαλιναγωγέω
div1.sense: to guide with or as with a bridle, to bridle, Luc., NTest.

div1.head: χαλινοποιική
div1.sense: (sc. τέχνη) , bridle-making, Arist.

div1.head: χαλινός
div1.sense: a bridle, bit, Il.; χαλινὸν ἐμβαλεῖν γνάθοις Eur.:—of the horse, χαλινὸν οὐκ ἐπίσταται φέρειν Aesch.; χ. δέχεσθαι Xen.; χ. ἐνδακεῖν to champ the bit, Plat.:—of the rider, τὸν χ. διδόναι to give a horse the rein, Xen.; ὀπίσω σπᾶν Plat.
metaph. of anything which curbs or restrains, of an anchor, Pind.; χαλινοῖς ἐν πετρίνοισι, of Prometheus bound to the rock, Aesch.
generally, a strap or thong, Eur. Hence

div1.head: χαλινόω
div1.sense: to bridle or bit a horse, Xen.

div1.head: χαλίνωσις
div1.sense: a bridling, Xen.

div1.head: χαλινωτήρια
div1.sense: (sc. ὅπλα) , τά, cables or ropes to moor ships to the shore, Eur.

div1.head: χάλιξ
div1.sense: a small stone, pebble, in pl., Luc., etc.
as collect. in sg., gravel, rubble, used in building, Thuc.; so also in pl., Ar.

div1.head: χάλις
div1.sense: sheer wine, Lat. merum, Hippon.

div1.head: χαλιφρονέω
div1.sense: to be lightminded, Od.

div1.head: χαλιφροσύνη
div1.sense: levity, thoughtlessness, Od.

div1.head: χαλίφρων
div1.sense: light-minded, thoughtless, Od.

div1.head: χαλκάρματος
div1.sense: with brasen chariot, Pind.

div1.head: χάλκασπις
div1.sense: with brasen shield, Pind., Soph.:—of one who ran the armed footrace, Pind.

div1.head: χαλκεγχής
div1.sense: with brasen lance, Eur.

div1.head: χαλκεία
div1.sense: smithʼs work, opp. to τεκτονική (joinerʼs work), Plat.

div1.head: χαλκεῖον
div1.sense: a smithʼs shop, forge, smithy, Hdt., Plat.
= χαλκίον, a copper, caldron, Hdt., Plat.
a metal reflector in a lamp, Xen.

div1.head: χάλκειος
div1.sense: of copper or bronze, brasen, Hom.; χαλκήιος δόμος, χαλκεῖον, a forge, Od.; χάλκειον γένος, of the Age of brass, Hes.

div1.head: χαλκέμβολος
div1.sense: with bronze beak: as the name of a special kind of ship, Plut.

div1.head: χαλκεντής
div1.sense: brass-armed, Pind.

div1.head: χαλκεοθώραξ
div1.sense: with brasen breastplate, Il.

div1.head: χαλκεοκάρδιος
div1.sense: with heart of brass, Theocr.

div1.head: χαλκεομήστωρ
div1.sense: skilled in arms, Eur.

div1.head: χαλκεόπεζος
div1.sense: brass-footed, Anth.

div1.head: χαλκέοπλος
div1.sense: with arms of brass, Eur.

div1.head: χάλκεος
div1.sense: of copper or bronze, brasen, Lat. aeneus, aheneus, Hom., etc.; χ. Ζεύς a bronze statue of Zeus, Hdt.; ἡ χαλκῆ Ἀθηνᾶ Dem.; χάλκεον ἱστάναι τινά (v. ἵστημι A. III).
χ. ἀγών a contest for a shield of brass, Pind.
metaph. brasen, i. e. stout, strong, χάλκεον ἦτορ, a heart of brass, Il.; ὂψ χ. Il.; χ. ὕπνος, i. e. the sleep of death, Virg. ferreus somnus, Il.
as Subst., v. χαλκοῦς.

div1.head: χαλκεοτευχής
div1.sense: armed in brass, Eur.

div1.head: χαλκεόφωνος
div1.sense: with voice of brass, i. e. strong and clear, Il., Hes.

div1.head: χάλκευμα
div1.sense: anything made of brass, e. g. an axe or sword, Aesch.

div1.head: χαλκεύς
div1.sense: a worker in copper, a smith, opp. to τέκτων (a joiner), Il.
generally, a worker in metal, a smith, Od., Hdt., etc.

div1.head: χαλκευτικός
div1.sense: of or for the smithʼs art, Xen.
of persons, skilled in metal-working, Xen.:— ἡ -κή (sc. τέχνη) , the smithʼs art or trade, Xen.

div1.head: χαλκευτός
div1.sense: wrought of metal, wrought, Anth.

div1.head: χαλκεύω
div1.sense: to make of copper or (generally) of metal, to forge, Il., Soph., etc.:—Mid. to forge for oneself, Theogn., Ar.:—Pass. to be wrought or forged, Ar.
absol. to be a smith, work as a smith, ply the hammer, Ar., Thuc.; τὸ χαλκεύειν the smithʼs art, Xen.

div1.head: χαλκέων
div1.sense: a forge, smithy, Od.

div1.head: χαλκηδών
div1.sense: a precious stone, chalcedony, NTest.

div1.head: χαλκήλατος
div1.sense: of beaten brass, Aesch., Eur.

div1.head: χαλκήρης
div1.sense: fitted with brass, tipped with brass, of arms, Il.

div1.head: Χαλκιδικός
div1.sense: of or from Chalcis, Hdt., Ar.

div1.head: χαλκίοικος
div1.sense: dwelling in a brasen house, epith. of Athena at Sparta, from the brasen shrine in which her statue stood, Eur., Thuc.

div1.head: χαλκίον
div1.sense: a copper vessel, a copper, caldron, kettle, pot, Ar., Xen.
a cymbal, Theocr.
a copper ticket given to the dicasts, Dem.
a piece of copper money, a copper, Ar.

div1.head: Χαλκίς
div1.sense: Chalcis in Euboea, said to have its name from neighbouring copper-mines, Il., Hes.:—the people were Χαλκιδεῖς, Ionic -έες, acc. -έας, Hdt., Ar.

div1.head: χαλκοάρας
div1.sense: brass-armed, Pind.

div1.head: χαλκοβαρής
div1.sense: heavy or loaded with brass, Hom.:—also fem. χαλκοβάρεια, (as if from χαλκόβαρυς) , Hom.

div1.head: χαλκοβατής
div1.sense: standing on brass, with brasen base, or with floor of brass, χαλκοβατὲς δῶ, of the house of Zeus, Hom.

div1.head: χαλκόγενυς
div1.sense: with teeth of brass, Pind.

div1.head: χαλκογλώχιν
div1.sense: with point or barb of brass, Il.

div1.head: χαλκοδαίδαλος
div1.sense: working in brass, Anth.

div1.head: χαλκοδάμας
div1.sense: subduing, i. e. sharpening, brass, Pind.

div1.head: χαλκόδετος
div1.sense: brass-bound, Trag.

div1.head: χαλκοκνήμις
div1.sense: brass-greaved, Il.

div1.head: χαλκοκορυστής
div1.sense: armed or equipt with brass, Il.

div1.head: χαλκόκροτος
div1.sense: sounding with brass, i. e. with brasen cymbals, Pind.: of horses, brasen-hoofed, Ar.

div1.head: χαλκολίβανον
div1.sense: an uncertain word in NTest. commonly taken to mean fine brass.

div1.head: χαλκομίτρας
div1.sense: with girdle of brass, Pind.

div1.head: χαλκόνωτος
div1.sense: brass-backed, Eur.

div1.head: χαλκοπαγής
div1.sense: made of brass, Anth.

div1.head: χαλκοπάρῃος
div1.sense: with cheeks or sides of brass, of helmets, Hom.; of a javelin, Pind.

div1.head: χαλκόπεδος
div1.sense: with floor of brass, Pind.

div1.head: χαλκόπλευρος
div1.sense: with sides of brass, τύπωμα χαλκ., of a cinerary urn, Soph.

div1.head: χαλκοπληθής
div1.sense: armed all in brass, Eur.

div1.head: χαλκόπληκτος
div1.sense: smiting with brasen edge or = χαλκήλατος, Soph.

div1.head: χαλκόπους
div1.sense: of horses, to express the solid strength of their hoofs, brass-hoofed, Il.; χ. Ἐρινύς, to express her untiring pursuit, Soph.; χαλκόπους ὀδός, simply, the threshold of brass, Soph.

div1.head: χαλκόπυλος
div1.sense: with gates of bronze, Hdt.; χαλκ. θεά, epith. of Athena, Eur.

div1.head: χαλκοπώγων
div1.sense: = Lat. Ahenobarbus, Plut.

div1.head: χαλκός
div1.sense: copper, Lat. aes, Hom., etc.; called in reference to its colour, ἐρυθρός, Il.:—copper was the first metal wrought for use, τοῖς δʼ ἦν χάλκεα μὲν τεύχη χάλκεοι δέ τε οἶκοι, χαλκῷ δʼ ἐργάζοντο, μέλας δʼ οὐκ ἔσκε σίδηρος Hes.:—hence χαλκός came to be used for metal in general; and, when men learnt to work iron, χαλκός was used for σίδηρος, and χαλκεύς came to mean a blacksmith. χαλκός also meant bronze (i. e. copper alloyed with tin), not brass (i. e. copper alloyed with zinc, which was a later invention), and this was its sense when applied to arms.
anything made of brass or metal, as a spear, sword, knife, etc., Il.; χαλκὸν ζώννυσθαι of a warrior girding on his armour, Il., etc.
of vessels, a copper, caldron, urn, Hom., etc.
of a brasen mirror, Anth.
a copper coin, like χαλκοῦς II, Anth.

div1.head: χαλκοστέφανος
div1.sense: brass-crowned, τέμενος Anth.

div1.head: χαλκόστομος
div1.sense: with brasen mouth, χ. κώδων Τυρσηνική, i. e. a trumpet, Soph.
with edge or point of brass, Aesch.

div1.head: χαλκότευκτος
div1.sense: made of brass, Eur.

div1.head: χαλκότοξος
div1.sense: armed with brasen bow, Pind.

div1.head: χαλκοτορέω
div1.sense: to work or form of brass, Anth.

div1.head: χαλκότορος
div1.sense: wrought of brass, Pind.

div1.head: χαλκοτύπος
div1.sense: a worker in copper, coppersmith, Xen.; a smith, Dem.

div1.head: χαλκότυπος
div1.sense: pass. struck with brass, inflicted with brasen arms, Il.

div1.head: χαλκουργικός
div1.sense: of or for a coppersmith: ἡ -κή (sc. τέχνη) the art of working in brass or bronze, Arist.

div1.head: χαλκουργός
div1.sense: a coppersmith, Luc.

div1.head: χαλκοῦς
div1.sense: a copper coin, 1/8 an obol, somewhat less than a farthing, Dem., etc.

div1.head: χαλκοφάλαρος
div1.sense: adorned with brass, Ar.

div1.head: χαλκοχάρμης
div1.sense: fighting in brass, i. e. in brasen armour, Pind.

div1.head: χαλκοχίτων
div1.sense: brass-clad, Il.

div1.head: χαλκόχυτος
div1.sense: cast in bronze, Anth.

div1.head: χαλκόω
div1.sense: to make in bronze, Anth.:— Pass., χαλκωθείς clad in brass, Pind.

div1.head: χάλκωμα
div1.sense: anything made of bronze or copper, a brass utensil, vessel, instrument, Ar., Xen.: the brasen beak of a ship, Plut.

div1.head: Χαλυβδικός
div1.sense: Chalybian: Χαλυβδικόν, οῦ, steel, Eur.

div1.head: Χάλυψ
div1.sense: one of the nation of the Chalybes in Pontus, famous for the preparation of steel, Hdt., etc.; οἱ σιδηροτέκτονες Χάλυβες Aesch.
as appellat., χάλυψ, hardened iron, steel, Aesch., Soph.

div1.head: χαμάδις
div1.sense: to the ground, on the ground, Il., Aesch.

div1.head: χαμᾶζε
div1.sense: to the ground, on the ground, Lat. humi, Hom., Eur., Ar.

div1.head: χαμᾶθεν
div1.sense: from the ground, Hdt., Ar.

div1.head: χαμαιγενής
div1.sense: earth-born, Hes., Pind.

div1.head: χαμαιεύνης
div1.sense: lying, sleeping on the ground, Il.:—fem. χαμαι-ευνάς, άδος, Od.

div1.head: χαμαίζηλος
div1.sense: seeking the ground, low-growing, dwarf, χ. φυτά Arist.:— χαμαίζηλος (sc. δίφρος) , a low seat, stool, Plat.
metaph. of low estate, Luc.

div1.head: χαμαικοιτέω
div1.sense: to lie on the ground, Luc.

div1.head: χαμαιλέων
div1.sense: the chameleon, a kind of lizard known for changing its colour, Arist., Plut.

div1.head: χαμαί
div1.sense: on the earth, on the ground, Lat. humi, Hom., Hdt., Attic
metaph., χ. καλύπτειν to bury underground, Pind.; χ. ἔρχεσθαι to be humble, modest, Luc.
= χαμᾶζε, χαμάδις, Il., Eur.

div1.head: χαμαιπετής
div1.sense: falling to the ground, Eur.; χ. φόνος blood that has fallen on the earth, Eur.; χαμαιπετεῖς ἔκεισθε ye were lying prostrate, Aesch.
lying on the ground, Plat.
on the ground, εὐνή Eur.
adv. -τῶς, along the ground, like a gooseʼs flight, Luc.
metaph. falling to the ground, i. e. coming to naught, Pind.
grovelling, low, of style, Luc.

div1.head: χαμαιτυπεῖον
div1.sense: a brothel, Luc.

div1.head: χαμερπής
div1.sense: creeping on the ground, grovelling, Anth.

div1.head: χαμεύνη
div1.sense: a bed on the ground, pallet-bed, Aesch., Eur.: generally, a bedstead, Ar.

div1.head: χαμηλός
div1.sense: on the ground, creeping, Anth.: of a horseʼs hoofs, Xen.
diminutive, trifling, Anth.; χαμηλὰ πνέων one of a low spirit, Pind.

div1.head: χάμψαι
div1.sense: Egyptian name for κροκόδ(ε)ιλοι, Hdt.

div1.head: Χαναναῖος
div1.sense: a Canaanite or (more correctly) Chanaanite, NTest.

div1.head: χανδάνω
div1.sense: to take in, hold, comprise, contain, λέβης τέσσαρα μέτρα κεχανδώς a caldron containing four measures, Il.; οὐκ ἐδυνήσατο πάσας αἰγιαλὸς νῆας χαδέειν the beach could not hold all the ships, Il.; Ἥρηι δʼ οὐκ ἔχαδε στῆθος χόλον the breast of Hera could not contain her rage, Il.; ὡς οἱ χεῖρες ἐχάνδανον as much as his hands could hold, Od.
metaph. to be capable, ἤυσεν ὅσον κεφαλὴ χάδε Il.; κεκραξόμεσθά γʼ ὁπόσον ἡ φάρυγξ ἂν χανδάνηι Ar.

div1.head: χανδόν
div1.sense: with mouth wide open, greedily, Od., Luc.

div1.head: χάος
div1.sense: chaos, the first stateof the universe, Hes., etc.
infinite space, the expanse, Ar.
the nether abyss, infinite darkness, Anth.

div1.head: χάραγμα
div1.sense: any mark engraven or imprinted, χ. ἐχίδνης the serpentʼs mark, i. e. its bite, Soph.; τὸ χ. τοῦ θηρίου the mark of the beast, NTest.; χ. τέχνης carved work, NTest.; τὸ χ. τοῦ νομίσματος the impress on the coin, Plut.: absol. an inscription, Anth.

div1.head: χαράδρα
div1.sense: a mountain stream, a torrent, which cuts itself (χαράσσει) a way down the mountain-side, Il.:—hence, a loud, brawling voice is compared to the φωνὴ χαράδρας, Ar.
the bed of a torrent, a gully, ravine, Il., etc.
a conduit for carrying rain-water off a road, Dem.

div1.head: χαραδριός
div1.sense: perh. a yellowish bird dwelling in clefts the curlew, Ar.: χαραδριοῦ βίον ζῆν, of a glutton, Plat.

div1.head: χαραδρόομαι
div1.sense: Pass.:— to be broken into clefts by mountain-streams, to be intersected by ravines, Hdt.

div1.head: χαρακοποιία
div1.sense: the making of a vallum, Polyb.

div1.head: χαρακόω
div1.sense: to fence by a palisade, fortify, Aeschin., Plut.

div1.head: χαρακτήρ
div1.sense: a mark engraved or impressed, the impress or stamp on coins and seals, Eur.; εὐδοξίας χαρακτῆρα τοῖς ἔργοις ἐπέβαλεν set a stamp of good repute upon them, Isocr.

metaph. the mark impressed (as it were) on a person or thing, a distinctive mark, characteristic, character, χ. γλώσσης of a particular language or dialect, Hdt.; of persons, ὁ χ. τοῦ προσώπου Hdt.; ἀνδρῶν οὐδεὶς χ. ἐμπέφυκε σώματι no outward mark has been set by nature on the person of men, Eur.; φανερὸς χ. ἀρετᾶς Eur.

div1.head: χαρακτός
div1.sense: notched, toothed,
div1.etym: like a saw or file, Anth.

div1.head: χαράκωμα
div1.sense: a place paled round, an entrenched camp, Xen., Plut.
a palisade, rampart, Lat. vallum, Xen., Dem.

div1.head: χαράκωσις
div1.sense: a palisading, Lycurg., Plut.

div1.head: χάραξ
div1.sense: a pointed stake: esp.,
a vine-prop or pole, Ar., Thuc.
a pale, used in entrenchments, Ar., Dem.
collectively, = χαράκωμα II, Dem., Polyb.

div1.head: χαρά
div1.sense: joy, delight, Trag., etc.;—but c. gen. objecti, joy in or at a thing, Eur.; κέρτομος θεοῦ χ. a joy sent by some god to grieve my heart, Eur.:— χαρᾷ with joy, Aesch.; so, χαρᾶς ὕπο Aesch.; σὺν χαρᾷ Soph.
a joy, of persons, NTest.

div1.head: χαράσσω
div1.sense: to make sharp or pointed, sharpen, whet, Hes.

to furnish with notches or teeth, like a saw, Arist.:—Pass., σκύταλον κεχ. ὄζοις a staff jagged or rugged with branches, Theocr.: metaph., ὄμμα ἠλεμάτοις ἀκτῖσι χαράσσεται sparkles with false lights, of the effect produced by painting the eye-lids, Anth.
metaph. in Pass., κεχαραγμένος τινί exasperated at any one, Hdt.; κείνῳ τόδε μὴ χαράσσου be not angry at him for this, Eur.
to cut into furrows, cut, scratch, Pind.:—Pass., κέκοπται καὶ χαράσσεται πέδον Aesch.
to engrave, inscribe, Theocr., Anth.

div1.head: χαριδώτης
div1.sense: joy-giver, Hhymn.

div1.head: χαρίεις
div1.sense: graceful, beautiful, lovely, Hom.
in Attic graceful, elegant, accomplished, οἱ χαρίεντες men of taste and refinement, men of education, Isocr., Plat.
so of things, graceful, elegant, neat, pretty, Ar., Plat.; —iron., χαρίεν γάρ, εἰ . . it would be a pretty thing, if . . ! Xen.
adv. χαριέντως, gracefully, elegantly, neatly, daintily, cleverly, Plat.
kindly, courteously, Isocr.
the neut. as adv., when it was written proparox. χάριεν, Ar., Plat.

div1.head: χαριεντίζομαι
div1.sense: Dep.:— to be witty, to jest, Lat. festive loqui, σπουδῇ χαριεντίζεσθαι to jest in earnest, Plat.

div1.head: χαριεντισμός
div1.sense: wittiness, wit, Plat.

div1.head: χαριεργός
div1.sense: elegantly working, artistic, Anth.

div1.head: χαρίζω
div1.sense: to say or do something agreeable to a person, shew him favour or kindness, to oblige, gratify, favour, humour, Lat. gratificari, c. dat. pers., Hom., Hdt., Attic:—absol. to make oneself agreeable, court favour, comply, Aesch., Dem.; c. dat. modi, μή μοι ψεύδεσσι χαρίζεο do not court favour with me by lies, Od.; τῶι αὐτῶι by the same arts, Thuc.
in Attic to gratify or indulge a humour or passion, like Lat. indulgere, θυμῶι Soph.; γλώσσηι Eur.; etc.
to humour another in argument, i. e. let him have the best of it, Plat.
c. acc. rei, to offer willingly, give cheerfully, give freely, Hom., Hdt., Attic
c. gen. partit. to give freely of a thing, χ. ἀλλοτρίων Od.; χαριζομένη παρεόντων giving freely of such things as were ready, Od.
c. acc. pers. to give up as a favour, i. e. not after lawful trial, NTest., Plut.
to forgive, Lat. condonare, NTest.
Pass. to be pleasing, agreeable, τοῖσι Εὐβοέεσσι ἐκεχάριστο it was done to please the Euboeans, Hdt.; ταῦτα μὲν οὖν μνήμηι κεχαρίσθω Plat.:—adv. κεχαρισμένως, Ar.

div1.head: χάρισμα
div1.sense: a grace, favour: a free gift, gift of Godʼs grace, NTest.

div1.head: χάρις
div1.sense: Grace, Lat. gratia:

outward grace or favour (as we say well or ill favoured), grace, loveliness, Hom., etc.; τῷγε χάριν κατεχεύατʼ Ἀθήνη over him Athena shed grace, Od.; of persons, pl. graces, charms, Od., etc.:—more rarely of things, ἔργοισι χάριν καὶ κῦδος ὀπάζειν Od.; ἡ τῶν λόγων χ. Dem.
grace or favour felt, whether on the part of the Doer or the Receiver:
on the part of the Doer, grace, graciousness, kindness, goodwill, τινός for or towards one, Hes., Thuc., etc.

on the part of the Receiver, the sense of favour received, thankfulness, thanks, gratitude, Il.; τινός for a thing, οὐδέ τίς ἐστι χάρις μετόπισθʼ εὐεργέων Od.; c. inf., οὔ τις χάρις ἦεν μάρνασθαι one has no thanks for fighting, Il.; χάριν εἰδέναι τινί to acknowledge a sense of favour, feel grateful, Il., Hdt., Attic:— χ. ἔχειν τινί τινος to feel gratitude to one for a thing, Hdt., Attic; χ. ὀφείλειν to owe gratitude, be beholden, Soph.; χάριν κατατίθεσθαί τινι to lay up a store of gratitude with a person, i. e. earn his thanks, Hdt., etc.; χάριν λαμβάνειν τινός to receive thanks from one, Soph.; so, κτᾶσθαι χάριν Soph.; χ. κομίσασθαι Thuc.
favour, influence, as opp. to force, χάριτι πλεῖον ἢ φόβῳ Thuc.

a favour done or returned, a grace, kindness, boon, χάριν φέρειν τινί to confer a favour on one, to please him, do a thing to oblige him, Hom.; χάριν θέσθαι τινί Hdt., Attic; so, χ. ὑπουργεῖν τινι Aesch.; παρασχεῖν Soph.; νέμειν Soph.; δοῦναι Aesch.:— χ. τίνειν to return a favour, Aesch.; ἀντιδιδόναι Thuc.; ἀποδιδόναι Plat.: —χ. ἀποστερεῖν to withhold a return for what one has received, Plat.
a gratification, delight, τινός in or from a thing, Pind., Eur., etc.
δαιμόνων χάρις homage due to them, their worship, majesty, Aesch.; so, ὅρκων χ. Eur.; εὐκταία χ. an offering in consequence of a vow, Aesch.
Special usages:

acc. sg. as adv., χ. τινός in any oneʼs favour, for his pleasure, for his sake, χάριν Ἕκτορος Il.; γλώσσης χάριν for oneʼs tongueʼs pleasure, i. e. for talkingʼs sake, Hes.:—then much like a prep., Lat. gratia, causa, for the sake of, on account of, τοῦ χάριν; for what reason? Ar.; so, ἐμὴν χάριν, σὴν χάριν for my, thy pleasure or sake, Lat. mea, tua gratia, Aesch., Eur.:—also, χάριν τινός as far as regards, as to, ἔπους σμικροῦ χ. Soph.

with Preps., εἰς χάριν τινός to do one a pleasure, Thuc.; οὐδὲν εἰς χ. πράσσειν Soph.:— πρὸς χάριν πράσσειν τι Soph.; πρὸς χάριν λέγειν Eur., etc.; πρὸς χάριν βορᾶς for the sake of my flesh, for the pleasure of devouring it, Soph.:— πρὸς χάριν alone, as a favour, freely, to their heartʼs content, Soph.:— ἐν χάριτι for oneʼs gratification, pleasure, ἐν χάριτι διδόναι or ποιεῖν τινί τι Xen., Plat.:— διὰ χαρίτων εἶναι or γίγνεσθαί τινι to be on terms of friendship or mutual favour with one, Xen.
Χάρις, ιτος, ἡ, as a mythological pr. n., Charis, wife of Hephaestus, Il.

mostly in pl. Χάριτες, αἱ, the Charites or Graces, Lat. Gratiae, who confer all grace, even the favour of Victory in the games, Pind.:—in Hom. their number is undefined; Hes. first reduced them to three, Aglaia, Euphrosyne, Thalia.

div1.head: χαριστέος
div1.sense: one must gratify, τινί Plat.
one must give freely, Arist.

div1.head: χαριστήριος
div1.sense: of or for thanksgiving, Plut.
as Subst., χαριστήριον, ου, a thank-offering: in pl. χαριστήρια, ων, τά, thank-offerings, Xen.

div1.head: χαριτία
div1.sense: a jest, joke, Xen.

div1.head: χαριτοβλέφαρος
div1.sense: with eyelids or eyes like the Charites, Anth.

div1.head: χαριτογλωσσέω
div1.sense: to speak to please, gloze with the tongue, Aesch.

div1.head: χαριτόω
div1.sense: to shew grace to any one, τινά NTest.:—Pass. to have grace shewn one, to be highly favoured, NTest.

div1.head: χαριτώπης
div1.note: χαρῐτ-ώπης, ου, ὁ, fem. χαριτῶπις, ιδος,
div1.sense: graceful of aspect, Anth.

div1.head: χάρμα
div1.sense: in concrete sense, a source of joy, a joy, delight, τινί to any one, Il.; also, χ. τινός oneʼs delight, Eur.; oft. in pl. joys, delights, Od., etc.
a source of malignant joy, Il.; χάρματα ἐχθροῖς Aesch.
joy, delight, Od., Hes.

div1.head: χάρμη
div1.sense: the joy of battle, lust of battle, Hom.: hence it passed into the sense of battle, Il.

div1.head: χαρμονή
div1.sense: a joy, Eur.; pl. joys, delights, Eur.
= χάρμα II, joy, delight, Soph., Xen.

div1.head: χαρμόσυνος
div1.sense: joyful, glad: χαρμόσυνα ποιεῖν to make rejoicings, Hdt.

div1.head: χαρμόφρων
div1.sense: heart-delighting, or of joyous heart, Hhymn.

div1.head: χαροπός
div1.sense: glad-eyed, bright-eyed, χαροποὶ λέοντες Od., Hes.; θῆρες Soph.:—later, it denoted light-blue or grayish colour, ὄμματά μοι γλαυκᾶς χαροπώτερα πολλὸν Ἀθάνας Theocr.; also of the Germans, v. χαροπότης.
of the eyes of youths, sparkling with joy, joyous, gladsome, Theocr., Anth.

div1.head: χαροπότης
div1.sense: brightness of eye: a light-blue colour, Plut.

div1.head: χάρτη
div1.sense: a sheet of paper, to which the Stoics compared the soul at birth, dub. in Plut.

div1.head: χάρτης
div1.sense: Lat. charta, a leaf of paper, made from the separated layers of the papyrus, Anth.

div1.head: χαρτός
div1.sense: that is matter of delight, causing delight, welcome, Lat. gratus, Soph., Plat.:— χαρτά delights, Eur.; t6o xapt4on Plut.
of persons, εἰ χαρτὸς ἀνέλθοι Anth.

div1.head: Χάρυβδις
div1.sense: Ionic ιος, Charybdis, a dangerous whirlpool on the coast of Sicily, opposite the Italian rock Scylla, Od., Eur., etc.
generally, a whirlpool, gulf, Eur.
metaph. of a rapacious person, Lat. barathrum, χ. ἁρπαγῆς Ar.

div1.head: Χαρωνῖται
div1.sense: Lat. Orcini, Senators brought up from the nether world (i. e. from the lower ranks), such as were created by the will of Caesar, Plut.

div1.head: Χάρων
div1.etym: poetic for χαροπός· hence as prop. n.
div1.sense: Charon, the ferryman of the Styx, from his bright fierce eyes, Eur., Ar.

div1.head: χασκάζω
div1.sense: to keep gaping at or after one, Ar.

div1.head: χάσκω
div1.sense: Lat. hio, to yawn, gape, τότε μοι χάνοι εὐρεῖα χθών then may earth yawn for me, i. e. to swallow me, Il.; πρὸς κῦμα χανών, of one drowning, Od.
to gape (in eager expectation), χάσκοντες κούφαις ἐλπίσι τερπόμεθα Solon; ὅτε δὴ ʼκεχήνη when I was all agape, Ar.; so, πρὸς ταῦτα κεχηνώς Ar.; κεχηνότες gaping fools, Ar.
to yawn (from weariness, ennui, or inattention), Ar.
more rarely, to speak with open mouth, to utter, Lat. hisco, c. acc., τὰ δεινὰ ῥήματα χανεῖν; Soph.; τοῦτʼ ἐτόλμησεν χανεῖν; Ar. Hence

div1.head: χάσμα
div1.sense: a yawning hollow, chasm, gulf, Hdt., etc.; of Tartarus, Hes., Eur., Hdt.
= χάσμημα, Eur.
generally, any wide expanse, χάσμα πελάγεος τὸ δὴ Αἰγαῖον καλέεται Hdt.

div1.head: χασμάομαι
div1.sense: to yawn, gape wide, Ar.
as Dep. χασμάομαι, Plat.

div1.head: χάσμημα
div1.sense: a wide yawn or gape, Lat. pictus, Ar.

div1.head: χάσμη
div1.sense: a yawning, gaping, Plat.

div1.head: χατέω
div1.sense: c. inf. to crave, long to do a thing, Od.; absol., χατέοντί περ ἔμπης Il.; μάλα περ χατέουσα Od.
c. gen. to crave, have need of, Od.

div1.head: χατίζω
div1.sense: to have need of, crave, c. gen., Hom.: absol., οὐδὲ χατίζων nor in want [of anything], Hom.: χατίζων a needy, poor person, Hes.
to lack, be without, χ. ἔργοιο, i. e. to be idle, Hes.:— Mid. to fail, be wanting, Aesch.

div1.head: χαυλιόδους
div1.sense: with outstanding teeth or tusks, Hes.
of the teeth, outstanding, tusky, ὀδόντες χαυλιόδοντες of the crocodileʼs teeth, Hdt.; also without ὀδόντας, τετράπουν χαυλιόδοντας φαῖνον of the hippopotamus, Hdt.

div1.head: χαυνοπολίτης
div1.sense: a gaping citizen, who swallows openmouthed all thatʼs told him (cf. Κεχηναῖοι) , Ar.

div1.head: χαυνόπρωκτος
div1.sense: wide-breeched, Ar.

div1.head: χαῦνος
div1.sense: gaping: hence, porous, spongy, loose, Plat.
metaph. unsubstantial, empty, frivolous, Solon., Pind., Ar.

div1.head: χαυνότης
div1.sense: porousness, sponginess, Xen., Plut.
metaph. empty vanity, Plat., Arist.

div1.head: χαυνόω
div1.sense: metaph. to puff up, fill with conceit, Eur., Plat.

div1.head: χαύνωμα
div1.sense: loosened earth, Plut.

div1.head: χαύνωσις
div1.sense: a making slack or loose, metaph. the making a thing light, weakening its force and weight (like Lat. elevatio), Ar.

div1.head: χέζω
div1.sense: to ease oneself, do oneʼs need, Ar.:—Pass., σπέλεθος ἀρτίως κεχεσμένος dung just dropt, Ar.

div1.head: χειά
div1.sense: a hole, esp. of serpents, Il., Pind.

div1.head: χειλοποτέω
div1.sense: to drink with the lips, sip, Anth.

div1.head: χεῖλος
div1.sense: a lip, Lat. labrum, Hom., etc.; proverb., χείλεσι γελᾶν to laugh with the lips only, Il.; χείλεα μέν τʼ ἐδίηνʼ, ὑπερῴην δʼ οὐκ ἐδίηνεν wetted the lips, but not the palate, i. e. drank sparingly, Il.; ἀπὸ χειλέων, opp. to ἀπὸ καρδίας, with "lip-service, " Plut.
of birds, a bill, beak, Eur.
metaph. of things, the edge, brink, brim, rim, of a bowl, Od., Hdt., etc.; of a ditch, Il., Hdt.; of rivers, Hdt.

div1.head: χειλόω
div1.sense: to surround with a lip or rim, Xen.

div1.head: χειμάδιον
div1.sense: a winter-dwelling, winter-quarters, χειμαδίῳ χρῆσθαι Λήμνῳ Dem.:—mostly in pl., χειμάδια πήγνυσθαι to fix oneʼs winter-quarters, Plut.

div1.head: χειμάζω
div1.sense: to pass the winter, opp. to θερίζω, Ar., Xen., etc.:—of armies, to go into winter-quarters, to winter, Lat. hiemare, Hdt., Xen.
to raise a storm or tempest, θεοῦ τοιαῦτα χειμάζοντος Soph.; ὅταν χειμάζῃ ὁ θεὸς ἐν τῇ θαλάσσῃ Xen.:—then,
impers., like ὕει, νίφει, ἐχείμαζε ἡμέρας τρεῖς (in imperf. sense) the storm continued for three days, Hdt.

c. acc. to agitate or distress like a storm, Soph.:— Pass. to be driven by a storm, suffer from it, Thuc.; χειμασθεὶς ἀνέμῳ Thuc.: metaph. to be tempest-tost, distressed, esp. of the state considered as a ship, Eur., Ar.; also of single persons, Trag., Plat.

div1.head: χειμαίνω
div1.sense: to drive by a storm:—Pass. to be driven by a storm, be tempest-tost, of a ship, Hdt.; metaph., φόβῳ κεχείμανται φρένες Pind.
intr. to be stormy, θάλασσα ἄγρια χειμήνασα Anth.: —impers., χειμαίνοντος when it is stormy, Theocr.

div1.head: χεῖμα
div1.sense: winter-weather, cold, frost, Lat. hiems, Hom.
winter as a season of the year, opp. to θέρος, Od., Attic; χεῖμα (acc. absol.) in winter, Od., Hes.; so dat. χείματι, Soph.
a storm, Aesch., Eur.

div1.head: χείμαρος
div1.sense: a plug in a shipʼs bottom, drawn out when the ship was brought on land, to let out the bilge-water, Hes.

div1.head: χειμάρροος
div1.sense: winter-flowing, swollen by rain and melted snow, ποταμὸς χ. Il., Hdt.; παρὰ ῥείθροισι χειμάρροις Soph.; φάραγγες ὕδατι χειμάρρῳ ῥέουσαι Eur.
as Subst. (without ποταμός) , a torrent, Xen., Dem.
like χαράδρα II. 2, a conduit, Dem.

div1.head: χειμαρρώδης
div1.sense: like a torrent, Strab.

div1.head: χειμασία
div1.sense: a passing the winter, wintering, Hdt.

div1.head: χειμασκέω
div1.sense: to exercise oneself in winter, Polyb.

div1.head: χειμερινός
div1.sense: of or in winter, of or in winter-time, opp. to θερινός, χ. τροπαί (v. τροπή 1), Hdt., Thuc., etc.; τὴν χ. (sc. ὥρην) during the winter season, Hdt.
wintry, Thuc.; v. χειμέριος.

div1.head: χειμέριος
div1.sense: wintry, stormy, Il., Hes., Soph.; ὥρη χειμερίη the wintry or stormy season, Od., Hes.; ἦμαρ χ. Il.; οἱ χειμεριώτατοι μῆνες the most wintry, stormy months, Hdt.; χ. νύξ a stormy night (in summer time), Thuc.; ἀκτὰ χειμερία κυματοπλήξ a shore stricken by the wintry waves, Soph.
metaph., χ. λύπη raging pain, Soph.— χειμέριος generally means wintry, stormy, χειμερινός in the winter season.

div1.head: χειμοφυγέω
div1.sense: to shun the winter or wintry weather, Strab.

div1.head: χειμών
div1.sense: winter, opp. to θέρος, il., Attic; χειμῶνος in winter-time, Xen.; τοῦ χ. in the course of the winter, Thuc.; χειμῶνα during winter, Soph.; τὸν χ. during the winter, Hdt., Xen.
the wintry quarter of the heavens, the north, Βορέας καὶ χ. Hdt.

wintry weather, a winter-storm, and generally a storm, Hom., Hdt., Attic; χ. κατερράγη Hdt.; ἐπέπεσέ σφι χ. μέγας Hdt.; ὦρσε θεὸς χειμῶνα Aesch.; χ. νοτερός a storm of rain, Thuc.:— in pl., ὑπὸ τῶν χ. by means of the winter-storms, Hdt.
metaph., θεόσσυτος χ. a storm of calamity sent by the gods, Aesch.; δορὸς ἐν χειμῶνι in the storm of battle, Soph.; θολερῷ χ. νοσήσας, of the madness of Ajax, Soph.

div1.head: χειραγωγέω
div1.sense: to lead by the hand, absol., Luc.

div1.head: χειραγωγός
div1.sense: one that leads by the hand, a leader, guide, NTest.

div1.head: χειραπτάζω
div1.sense: to touch with the hand, take in hand, handle, Hdt.

div1.head: χειριδωτός
div1.sense: having sleeves, sleeved, κιθὼν χειριδωτός, worn by Asiatics, Hdt.; cf. ἐξωμίς.

div1.head: χείριος
div1.sense: in the hands, in the power or control, Eur.; mostly with a Verb, χειρίαν ἐφείς τινι having left me as a captive to another, Soph.; χείριον λαβεῖν τινα to get him into oneʼs power, Eur.

div1.head: χειρίς
div1.sense: a covering for the hand, a glove, Od., Xen.: also a covering for the arm, a loose sleeve, such as the Persians wore, Lat. manica, Hdt.

div1.head: χειροδάϊκτος
div1.sense: slain by hand, Soph.

div1.head: χειρόδεικτος
div1.sense: Lat. digito monstratus, manifest, Soph.

div1.head: χειροδίκης
div1.sense: one who asserts his right by hand, uses the right of might, Hes.

div1.head: χειροδράκων
div1.sense: with serpent arms, Eur.

div1.head: χειροήθης
div1.sense: accustomed to the hand, manageable; of animals, submissive, tame, Lat. mansuetus, Hdt., Xen.
of things, tolerable, Plut.

div1.head: χειρόμακτρον
div1.sense: a cloth for wiping the hands, a towel, napkin, Lat. mantile, Hdt., Xen.

div1.head: χειρομύλη
div1.sense: a hand-mill, Xen.

div1.head: χειρονομέω
div1.sense: to move the hands in pantomimic gestures, to gesticulate, Xen.; τοῖς σκέλεσι χειρονομεῖν, of one standing on his head, Hdt.

div1.head: χειρονομία
div1.sense: gesticulation, Luc.

div1.head: χειροπληθής
div1.sense: filling the hand, as large as can be held in the hand, λίθος Xen.; κορύνη Theocr.

div1.head: χειροποιέομαι
div1.sense: to make by hand:—Mid., χειροποιεῖται τάδε perpetrates these acts, Soph.

div1.head: χειροποίητος
div1.sense: made by hand, artificial, opp. to αὐτοφυής (natural), Hdt.; φλὸξ χ. a fire kindled by the hand of man, Thuc.

div1.head: χειροτένων
div1.sense: with outstretched arms, of the crab, Batr.

div1.head: χειροτέχνημα
div1.sense: a work of art, Babr.

div1.head: χειροτέχνης
div1.sense: a handicraftsman, artisan, Hdt., Ar., etc.; τίς ὁ χ. ἰατορίας; who is the skilled surgeon? Soph.

div1.head: χειροτεχνία
div1.sense: handicraft, Plat.

div1.head: χειροτεχνικός
div1.sense: of or for handicraft, skilful, χειροτεχνικώτατος Ar.
of artisans, Plat.

div1.head: χειροτονέω
div1.sense: to stretch out the hand, for the purpose of voting, Plut., Luc.
c. acc. pers. to vote for, elect, properly by show of hands, Ar., Dem.:—Pass. to be elected, Ar., etc.; χειροτονηθῆναι, election, was opp. to λαχεῖν, appointment by lot, Plat., etc.
c. acc. rei, to vote for a thing, Dem.; so c. inf. to vote that . . , Aeschin.:— Pass., κεχειροτόνηται ὕβρις εἶναι it is voted, ruled to be violence, Dem.

div1.head: χειροτονητός
div1.sense: elected by show of hands, Aeschin.; ἀρχὴ χ. an elective magistracy, opp. to κληρωτή, Aeschin.

div1.head: χειροτονία
div1.sense: a voting or electing by show of hands, Thuc.
a vote, Lat. suffragium, in pl., Aeschin.

div1.head: χειρότονος
div1.sense: stretching out the hands, λιταὶ χ. offered with outstretched hands, Aesch.

div1.head: χειρουργέω
div1.sense: to do with the hand, execute, esp. of acts of violence, Thuc., Aeschin.
to have in hand, pursue practically, Arist.

div1.head: χειρούργημα
div1.sense: handiwork, Plat.

div1.head: χειρουργία
div1.sense: a working by hand, practice of a handicraft or art, skill herein, Plat., etc.
a handicraft, Plat.:—esp. the practice of chirurgery, surgery.

div1.head: χειρουργικός
div1.sense: of or for handiwork, Arist.

div1.head: χειρουργός
div1.sense: doing by hand, Plut.
χειρουργός, οῦ, a chirurgeon, surgeon, Plut., Anth.

div1.head: χειρόω
div1.sense: to bring into hand, to manage, master, subdue, Ar.
mostly in Mid., to conquer, overpower, subdue, Hdt., Trag., etc.: to take prisoner, Eur.; so, τήνδʼ ἐχειρούμην ἄγραν became master of this booty, Soph.
without any sense of violence, to master, subdue, Xen., etc.
χειροῦμαι is also Pass. to be subdued, Trag.; fut. χειρωθήσομαι Dem.; aor1 ἐχειρώθην Hdt., Soph.; perf. κεχείρωμαι Aesch., Thuc.

div1.head: χείρ
div1.etym: the penult. is regularly short, when the ult. is long: e.g. χειρός, χερών, but Poets used the penult. long or short, as the verse required.
div1.sense: the hand, Hom., etc.: also the hand and arm, the arm, χεῖρα μέσην ἀγκῶνος ἔνερθεν Il.; χεῖρες ἀπʼ ὤμων ἀΐσσοντο Hes.; so, ἐν χερσὶ πεσεῖν into the arms, Il., etc.; ἄκρη χείρ, to denote the hand as distinct from the arm, Il.
Special usages:
to denote position, ἐπʼ ἀριστερὰ χειρός Od.; ἐπὶ δεξιὰ χειρός Pind.; λαιᾶς χειρός on the left hand, Aesch.; ποτέρας τῆς χειρός; on which hand? Eur.
the dat. is common with Verbs which imply the use of hands, χειρὶ λαβεῖν, χερσὶν ἑλέσθαι, etc., Hom., etc.
the gen. is used when one takes a person by the hand, χειρὸς ἔχειν τινά Il.; χειρὸς ἑλών Il.
the acc. is used when one takes the hand of a person, χεῖρα γέροντος ἑλών Il.; χεῖράς τʼ ἀλλήλων λαβέτην, in pledge of good faith, Il.
other uses of the acc.:

of suppliants, χεῖρας ἀνασχεῖν θεοῖς, in prayer, Il.; χεῖρας ἀμφιβάλλειν γούνασι or δείρῃ Od.; also, χεῖρας αἴρειν is to hold up hands in voting, Xen., etc.:— χεῖρα ὑπερέχειν τινός or τινί to hold the hand over him as a protector, Il.
in hostile sense, χεῖρας or χεῖρα ἐπιφέρειν τινί, ἐφιέναι τινί Hom.
χεῖρας ἀπέχειν τινός to keep hands off a person or thing, Lat. abstinere manus ab aliquo, Hom.

with Preps., ἀπὸ χειρὸς λογίζεσθαι to reckon off hand, roughly, Ar.:— διὰ χερῶν λαβεῖν, literally, to take between the hands, Soph.; διὰ χειρὸς ἔχειν to have in hand, i. e. under control, Thuc.; and so, to have a work in hand, Thuc.: —so, εἰς χεῖρας λαμβάνειν to take in hand, undertake, Eur.; ἄγεσθαί τι ἐς χεῖρας Hdt.; ἐς χεῖρας ἱκέσθαι τινός to fall into his hands, Il.; ἐς χεῖρας ἐλθεῖν, ἰέναι τινί to come to blows or close quarters with, Lat. manum conserere cum aliquo, Aesch., Soph.; Hdt. expresses this by ἐς χειρῶν νόμον ἀπικέσθαι:—also, εἰς χεῖρας δέχεσθαι or ὑπομένειν to await their charge, Xen., Thuc.: —ἐκ χειρόςs from near at hand, close, Lat. cominus, Xen.:— ἐν χερσίν or ἐν χειρὶ ἔχειν, like διὰχειρὸς ἔχειν, to have in hand, be engaged in, Hdt., Plat.; ἐν χερσί hand to hand, Lat. cominus, Thuc.:— κατὰ χειρός, of washing the hands before meals, ὕδωρ κατὰ χειρός or κατὰ χειρὸς ὕδωρ (sc. φερέτω τις) , Ar.:— μετὰ χερσὶν ἔχειν between i. e. in, the hands, Il.; but, μετὰ χεῖρας ἔχειν to have in hand, be engaged in, Hdt., Thuc.:— πρὸ χειρῶν close before one, Soph., Eur.:— πρὸς χεῖρα at a sign given by hand, Soph.:— ὑπὸ χεῖρα ποιεῖσθαι to bring under oneʼs power, Xen.; cf. ὑποχείριος.

to denote act or deed, as opp. to mere words, in pl., ἔπεσιν καὶ χερσὶν ἀρήξειν Il.; χερσίν τε ποσίν τε Il.; χερσὶν ἢ λόγῳ Soph.; μιᾷ χειρί single- handed, Dem.; χειρὶ καὶ ποδὶ καὶ πάσῃ δυνάμει Aeschin.:—esp. of deeds of violence, πρὶν χειρῶν γεύσασθαι before we try force, Od.; ἀδίκων χειρῶν ἄρχειν to give the first blow, Xen.
like Lat. manus, a body of men, a band, number, Hdt., Thuc.; πολλῇ χ. Eur.; οἰκεία χείρ, for χεὶρ οἰκετῶν, Eur.
oneʼs hand, i. e. handwriting, NTest.: also a handiwork, a work of art, σοφαὶ χέρες Anth.
of any implement resembling a hand:
a kind of gauntlet or target, Xen.
χ. σιδηρᾶ a grappling- iron, grapnel, Thuc.

div1.head: χείρωμα
div1.sense: that which is conquered, a conquest, Aesch.
a deed of violence, assault, Soph.
a work wrought by the hand, τυμβοχόα χ., of earth thrown up, Aesch.

div1.head: χειρωναξία
div1.sense: handicraft, work, Hdt., Aesch.

div1.head: χειρῶναξ
div1.sense: one who is master of his hands, (ἄναξ τῶν χερῶν) , i. e. a handicraftsman, artisan, mechanic, Hdt.

div1.head: Χειρωνίς
div1.sense: (sc. βίβλος) , a book on surgery, Anth.

div1.head: χείρων
div1.etym: irreg. comp. and superl. of κακός
div1.sense: of persons, worse, meaner, inferior, Hom., etc.; σὺ μὲν ἐσθλός, ἐγὼ δὲ σέθεν πολὺ χείρων Il.: in moral sense, worse than others, a knave, Soph., Thuc., etc.
worse in quality, inferior, Il.; χ. εἰς τὴν ἀρετήν Plat.; χ. τὰ πολεμικά Xen.; c. inf., χ. ποιεῖν Xen.
of things, inferior, Il., Xen.
worse, more severe, νόσος Eur.; μοῖρα Plat.
the neut. is used,
as a Subst., τὰ χερείονα the worse advice, ill counsels, Il.: —ἐπὶ τὸ χεῖρον τρέπεσθαι, κλίνειν to fall off, get worse, Xen.
χεῖρόν τινι (sc. ἔστι or ἔσται) it is or will be worse for one, Od., Xen.; οὐ χεῖρον, in an answer, ʼtis well, Ar.
as adv., like Lat. pejus, worse, χεῖρον βουλεύεσθαι Thuc.; βιῶναι, ζῆν Plat.
in inferior degree, less, Xen., etc.
Sup. χείριστος, η, ον worst, Lat. pessimus, Plat., etc.: esp. οἱ χείριστοι men of lowest degree, Xen.

div1.head: Χείρων
div1.sense: Cheiron, one of the Centaurs, a famous chirurgeon (cf. χειρουργός II), teacher of Achilles, Il.

div1.head: χελιδόνιον
div1.sense: swallow-wort, celandine, Theocr., Anth.

div1.head: χελιδόνιος
div1.sense: of the swallow, like the swallow, esp. coloured like the swallowʼs throat, reddish-brown, russet, Ar.

div1.head: χελιδόνισμα
div1.sense: the swallow-song, an old song sung at the return of the swallows, cf. Ar. Av. 1410 sq.

div1.head: χελιδών
div1.sense: the swallow, Od., etc.:— the twittering of the swallow was proverbially used of barbarous tongues by the Greeks, Aesch.; χελιδόνων μουσεῖα (v. μουσεῖον) : proverbs also, μία χελιδὼν ἔαρ οὐ ποιεῖ Arist.
the frog in a horseʼs foot, so called from its being forked like the swallowʼs tail, Xen.

div1.head: χελύνη
div1.sense: the lip, Ar.

div1.head: χέλυς
div1.sense: a tortoise, Lat. testudo:—then, since Hermes made the lyre by stretching strings on its shell, which acted as a sounding-board, χέλυς came to mean the lyre, Hhymn. (to Merc.), Eur.
the arched breast, the chest, from its likeness of shape to the back of a tortoise, Eur.

div1.head: χελώνη
div1.sense: a tortoise, Hhymn., Hdt.; prov. of insensibility, ἰὼ χελῶναι μακάριαι τοῦ δέρματος oh ye tortoises, happy in your thick skins! Ar.

like Roman testudo, a pent-house formed of shields overlapping each other like the scales on a tortoiseʼs back, used by storming parties in approaching a cityʼs walls: then, generally, a pent-house for protecting besiegers, Xen.

div1.head: χέννιον
div1.sense: a kind of quail, Anth.

div1.head: χέραδος
div1.sense: the mud, sand, gravel, and rubbish, silt, brought down by torrents, Il.

div1.head: χερείων
div1.note: χερείων, Doric χερῄων, ονος, ὁ, ἡ,
div1.sense: meaner, inferior, in rank, worth or wealth, Hom.
of things, οὔ τι χέρειον ʼtis not the worse part, i. e. ʼtis the better part, Od.

besides this, we have several irreg. forms (as if from a nom. χέρης) , dat. χέρηι, acc. χέρηα, nom. pl. χέρηες, acc. neut. χέρηα, all used in compar. sense, χώσεται ἀνδρὶ χέρηι shall be wroth with a man of meaner rank, Il.; ἐσθλὰ μὲν ἐσθλὸς ἔδυνε, χέρηα δὲ χείρονι δόσκεν, where ἐσθλά ἐσθλός and χέρηα χείρονι are evidently correlative, Il.; with a gen., εἷο χέρηα inferior to himself, Il.; χέρηα πατρός Od.

div1.head: χεριάρης
div1.sense: skilled in fitting with the hand, dexterous, Pind.

div1.head: χεριφυρής
div1.sense: mixed or kneaded by hand, Anth.

div1.head: χερμάδιον
div1.sense: a large stone, a boulder, used as a missile, Hom.

div1.head: χερμαστήρ
div1.sense: a slinger, χ. ῥινός the leather of a sling, out of which the stone was thrown, Anth.

div1.head: χερνής
div1.sense: Doric χερνάς, ᾶτος, one who lives by his hands, a day-labourer, a poor man, Anth.
as adj. poor, needy, ἐν δόμοις χερνῆσι Eur.

div1.head: χερνητικός
div1.sense: of or for a day-labourer: τὸ χ., the proletariate, Arist.

div1.head: χερνῆτις
div1.sense: a woman that spins for daily hire, Il.

div1.head: χέρνιβον
div1.sense: a vessel for water to wash the hands, a basin, Il.

div1.head: χερνίπτομαι
div1.sense: Mid.
to wash oneʼs hands, esp. before sacrifice, Il., Ar., etc.
to sprinkle with holy water, purify or dedicate thereby, Eur.

div1.head: χέρνιψ
div1.sense: water for washing the hands, before meals, or before sacrifices and religious services, Od., Ar.

pl. χέρνιβες, purifications with holy water, Eur.; εἴργεσθαι χερνίβων to be excluded from the use thereof, as were those defiled by bloodshed, Dem.; χέρνιβας νέμειν to allow the use of it, Soph.; χερνίβων κοινωνός a partaker therein, i. e. a member of the household, Aesch.
rarely of libations to the dead, Aesch., Soph.

div1.head: χερομυσής
div1.sense: defiling the hand, Aesch.

div1.head: χερόπληκτος
div1.sense: stricken by the hand, χερόπληκτοι δοῦποι the sound of beating with the hand, Soph.

div1.head: χερσαῖος
div1.sense: on or of dry land, ὄρνιθες χ. land-birds, opp. to λιμναῖοι, Hdt.; χ. κροκόδειλος a lizard, Hdt.:—also of landsmen, as opp. to seamen, Eur., Thuc.; κῦμα χερσαῖον στρατοῦ, an army, opp. to a fleet, Aesch.

div1.head: χερσεύω
div1.sense: to be dry land, to lie waste or barren, Xen.

div1.head: χερσόθεν
div1.sense: from dry land, Eur.
from the ground, Pind.

div1.head: χερσόθι
div1.sense: on dry land, Anth.

div1.head: χέρσονδε
div1.sense: to or on dry land, Il., Theocr.

div1.head: χερσονησίζω
div1.sense: to form a χερσόνησος or peninsula, Polyb.

div1.head: χερσονήσιος
div1.note: χερσονήσιος, later Attic χερρ-ος, η, ον
div1.sense: of or like a peninsula: of the Thracian Chersonese, Eur.

div1.head: χερσονησίτης
div1.sense: a dweller in the Thracian Chersonese, Xen., Dem.

div1.head: χερσονησοειδής
div1.sense: like a peninsula, peninsular, of Mount Athos, Hdt.

div1.head: χερσόνησος
div1.sense: a land-island, i. e. a peninsula, Hdt.
as pr. n. the Chersonese, i. e. the peninsula of Thrace that runs along the Hellespont, Hdt.:—also the Tauric Chersonese, Crimea, Hdt.; the peninsula between Epidaurus and Troezen, Thuc.

div1.head: χέρσος
div1.sense: dry land, land, ἐπὶ χέρσου, opp. to ἐν πόντῳ, Od.; κύματα κυλινδόμενα προτὶ χέρσον Od.; κῦμα χέρσῳ ῥηγνύμενον Il.; χέρσῳ on or by land, Aesch., Eur.
as adj., χέρσος, ον, dry, firm, of land, Hdt.; ἐν κονίᾳ χέρσῳ, opp. to πόντῳ, Pind.
dry, hard, barren, Hdt., Soph.; χ. λιμήν a harbour left dry, Anth.
metaph. barren, without children, of women, Soph.: c. gen. barren of, πυρὰ χέρσος ἀγλαϊσμάτων Eur.
div1.etym: Prob. from same Root as ξηρός.

div1.head: χεσείω
div1.sense: Desiderat. of χέζω, Lat. cacaturio, Ar.

div1.head: χεῦμα
div1.sense: that which is poured, a stream, Il., Trag.
that into which water is poured, a bowl, Hdt.

div1.head: χέω
div1.sense: Radic. sense, to pour:

properly of liquids, to pour out, pour, Hom., etc.; Zeus χέει ὕδωρ, i. e. he makes it rain, Il.; χέει χιόνα βορέας Eur.; absol., χέει it snows, Il.:—Mid. to pour for oneself, esp. of drink-offerings, χοὰς χεόμην νεκύεσσι Od., etc.:—Pass., χέονται κρῆναι they gush forth, Eur.; χυθέντος ποτοῦ ἐς γῆν Soph.
χ. δάκρυα to shed tears, Il., Eur.:—Pass., of tears, to pour or gush forth, Hom.; so of blood, to be shed, Aesch.
in Pass. to become liquid, melt, thaw, Xen.
of solids, to shed, scatter, φύλλα Il.; πτερά Od.; χ. κόνιν κὰκ κεφαλῆς Hom.; χ. καλάμην χθονί, of a mower or reaper (v. καλάμη), Il.
like χώννυμι, to throw out earth, so as to form a mound, σῆμα, τύμβον χ. Hom.
χ. δοῦρα to pour or shower spears, Il.; Mid., βέλεα χέοντο they showered their arrows, Il.
to let fall or drop, ἡνία Il.; so, χέειν κρόκου βαφὰς (v. βαφή II) Aesch.; but, καρπὸν χ., of trees, to produce fruit abundantly, Od.
in Pass. to be thrown or heaped up together, Hom., Hdt.
in Pass. also of living beings, to pour or stream in a dense mass or throng, Hom.
metaph. of sounds, to pour forth, φωνήν, αὐδήν Od.; φθόγγον Aesch.

of things that obscure the sight, κατʼ ὀφθαλμῶν χέεν ἀχλύν shed a dark cloud over the eyes, Il.; πολλὴν ἠέρα χεῦε shed a mist abroad, Od.:—Pass., ἀμφὶ δέ οἱ θάνατος χύτο was shed around him, Il.; νόσος κέχυται Soph.; φρὶξ ἐπὶ πόντον ἐχεύατο (Mid. in pass. sense), Il.
of persons, ἀμφʼ αὐτῶι χυμένη throwing herself around him, Hom.: so in Mid., ἀμφὶ υἱὸν ἐχεύατο πήχεε Il.
perf. pass. κέχυμαι, to be wholly engaged in, Δᾶλος, ἐν ἇι κέχυμαι Pind.

div1.head: χηλαργός
div1.sense: with fleet hoofs, χ. ἅμιλλαι the racing of fleet horses, Soph.

div1.head: χηλευτός
div1.sense: netted, plaited, Hdt.

div1.head: χηλεύω
div1.sense: to net, plait, Eupol.

div1.head: χηλή
div1.sense: a horseʼs hoof, Hes., Eur.:—also, a cloven hoof, Eur.
in pl., of the talons of a bird, Trag.; of a wolfʼs claws, Theocr.
a sea-bank, breakwater, formed of stones laid at the base of a sea-wall, to break the force of the waves (so called because it projected like a hoof), Lat. crepido, Thuc., Xen.
the spur of a mountain or ridge of rocks answering a like purpose, Thuc.
a cloven implement, such as a netting-needle;— cf. χηλεύω.

div1.head: χηλός
div1.sense: a large chest or coffer, Hom., Theocr.

div1.head: χηναλώπηξ
div1.sense: the fox-goose, vulpanser, an Egyptian species, living in holes, Hdt., Ar.

div1.head: χήνειος
div1.sense: of or belonging to a goose, Lat. anserinus, Hdt.

div1.head: χηνίσκος
div1.sense: a shipʼs stern turned up like a gooseʼs neck, Luc.

div1.head: χήν
div1.sense: Lat. anser, the wild goose, Il.: the tame goose, Od., etc.:— νή or μὰ τὸν χῆνα was Socratesʼ form of oath, instead of Ζῆνα.

div1.head: χηραμός
div1.sense: a hole, cleft, hollow, Il.;of a mouseʼs hole, Babr.

div1.head: χήρα
div1.sense: bereft of a husband, a widow, Lat. vidua, c. gen., χήρη σευ ἔσομαι, says Andromache to Hector, Il.; χῆραι γυναῖκες widow women, Il.; so Eur., etc.
from χήρα was formed the masc. χῆρος (as widower from widow), Anth.
χῆρος, α, ον, as adj., in metaph. sense, widowed, bereaved, χῆρα μέλαθρα Eur.; c. gen., φάρσος στελεοῦ χῆρον a piece torn from the stem, Anth.

div1.head: χηρεία
div1.sense: widowhood, Thuc.

div1.head: χήρειος
div1.sense: widowed, Anth.

div1.head: χηρεύω
div1.sense: intr. to be bereaved of a person or thing, c. gen., Od., Theogn.
absol. to be bereaved of a husband, to be widowed, live in widowhood, Dem., etc.;—of a man, to be a widower, Plut.; so, χηρεύσει λέχος Eur.
to live in solitude, of an exile, Soph.
trans. to bereave, Eur.

div1.head: χηρόω
div1.sense: trans. to make desolate, χήρωσε δʼ ἀγυιάς Il.; χήρωσας γυναῖκα thou didʼst widow her, Il.
c. gen. to bereave of a thing, Anth.:—Pass., Ἄργος ἀνδρῶν ἐχηρώθη Hdt.
intr., like χηρεύω, to be bereft of, τινός Theogn.

div1.head: χηρωσταί
div1.sense: kinsmen, who divide the property of one who dies without heirs (χῆρος) Il.

div1.head: χῆτος
div1.sense: want, need, c. gen. pers., χήτεϊ τοιοῦδʼ ἀνδρός from want or need of such a man, Il.; χήτεϊ τοιοῦδʼ υἷος Il.

div1.head: χητοσύνη
div1.sense: need, destitution, loneliness, Anth.

div1.head: χθαμαλός
div1.sense: near the ground, on the ground, flat, Hom., Theocr.

div1.head: χθές
div1.sense: yesterday, Hhymn., Plat., etc.; οἱ χθὲς λόγοι Plat.; πρώην τε καὶ χθές or χθὲς καὶ πρώην (v. πρώην)

div1.head: χθιζός
div1.sense: of yesterday, τὸ χθιζὸν χρεῖος their yesterdayʼs debt, Il.; ὁ χθ. πόνος yesterdayʼs labour, Hdt.; in adverb. sense, with Verbs, χθιζὸς ἔβη he went yesterday, Il.; χθ. ἤλυθες Od., etc.:—neut. χθιζόν as adv. = χθές, Hom.; so pl. χθιζά, v. πρώιζος.

div1.head: χθόνιος
div1.sense: in, under or beneath the earth, Hes., Soph.; of subterranean noises, κτυπεῖ Ζεὺς χθ. Soph.; χθ. βροντήματα Aesch.:—also, χθόνιοι θεοί the gods of the nether world, Lat. Inferi, Aesch.; and χθόνιοι alone, Pind., Aesch.; χθόνιαι θεαί, i. e. Demeter and Persephone, Hdt.; of the Erinyes, Soph.; χθ. Ἑρμῆς, as conductor of the dead, Aesch., Soph.; χάρις ἡ χθονία grace with the gods below, Soph.
of or from the earth, of the Titans, as sons of Gaia, Hes., Aesch.
like ἐγχώριος, of persons, in or of the country, native, Soph.
of things, of the earth, χθ. κόνις Aesch.

div1.head: χθονοστιβής
div1.sense: treading the earth, Soph.

div1.head: χθονοτρεφής
div1.sense: bred from earth, Aesch.

div1.head: χθών
div1.sense: the earth, ground, Hom., Trag.;—to denote life upon the earth, ζῶντος καὶ ἐπὶ χθονὶ δερκομένοιο Il.; χθόνα δῦναι to go beneath the earth, i. e. to die, Il.; κατὰ χθονὸς κρύπτειν τινά Soph.; κούφα σοι χθὼν ἐπάνω πέσοι Eur.
of the nether world, οἱ ὑπὸ χθονός, i. e. those in the shades below, Lat. inferi, Aesch.; κατὰ χθονὸς θεαί, i. e. the Erinyes, Aesch.
earth, i. e. the whole earth, the world, Aesch., Soph.
Earth, as a goddess, Aesch.
a particular land or country, of Ithaca, Od.; of Libya, Pind.; χθὼν Ἀσιᾶτις, Δωρίς, Ἀργεία, Ἑλλάς, Ἰδαία, etc., Trag.

div1.head: χῖδρον
div1.sense: unripe wheaten groats, as ἄλφιτα are barley-groats, Ar.

div1.head: χιλιαρχέω
div1.sense: to be a χιλίαρχος, Plut.

div1.head: χιλιαρχία
div1.sense: the office or post of χιλίαρχος, Xen.
the office of the tribuni militares, Xen.

div1.head: χιλίαρχος
div1.sense: the commander of a thousand men, a chiliarch, Aesch., Xen.
used to translate the Roman tribunus militum, Polyb., etc.;—also of the tribuni militares consulari potestate, Plut.

div1.head: χιλιάς
div1.sense: the number one thousand, a thousand, Hdt., Aesch.; c. gen., πολλαὶ χιλιάδες ταλάντων Hdt.: —generally, a very large number, Theocr.

div1.head: χιλιέτης
div1.sense: lasting a thousand years, Plat.

div1.head: χίλιοι
div1.sense: a thousand, Lat. mille, Il.: it commonly agrees with its Subst., but is also a Subst. foll. by a gen., χίλιοι Πελοποννησίων Thuc.:—to express a thousand drachmae, χίλιαι is often used alone, περὶ χιλιῶν κινδυνεύειν Dem.: in military language in sg. with collective nouns, ἵππος χιλίη a thousand horse, Hdt.

div1.head: χιλιόναυς
div1.sense: of a thousand ships, Eur.

div1.head: χιλιοναύτης
div1.sense: with or of a thousand ships, Aesch., Eur.

div1.head: χιλιόπαλαι
div1.sense: a thousand times long ago, long long ago, Ar.

div1.head: χιλιοστός
div1.sense: the thousandth, Plat., Xen.

div1.head: χιλιοστύς
div1.sense: a body of a thousand, Xen.

div1.head: χιλιοτάλαντος
div1.sense: weighing or worth a thousand talents, Plut.

div1.head: χιλός
div1.sense: green fodder for cattle, forage, provender, Hdt., Xen.; προέρχεσθαι ἐπὶ χιλόν to go on to forage, Xen.:— χ. ξηρός hay, Xen.

div1.head: χιλόω
div1.sense: to feed horses in stall, Xen.

div1.head: Χιλώνειος
div1.sense: of or from Χίλων: τὸ Χ. the saying of Chilon, Arist.

div1.head: χίμαιρα
div1.sense: a she-goat, Lat. capra, Il., Hes., Attic
Χίμαιρα, ἡ, Chimaera, a firespouting-monster, with lionʼs head, serpentʼs tail, and goatʼs body, killed by Bellerophon, Il.

div1.head: χιμαιροθύτης
div1.sense: goat-sacrificer, Anth.

div1.head: χιμαιροφόνος
div1.sense: goat-slaying, Anth.

div1.head: χιμάραρχος
div1.sense: goat-leader, τράγος χ. the he-goat that leads the flock, Anth.

div1.head: χίμαρος
div1.sense: a he-goat, Lat. caper, = τράγος, Ar., Theocr.
also fem. = χίμαιρα, Theocr., Anth.

div1.head: χιμαροσφακτήρ
div1.sense: a goat-slayer, Anth.

div1.head: χίμετλον
div1.sense: a chilblain, kibe, Lat. pernio, Ar.

div1.head: Χιογενής
div1.sense: of Chian growth, of wine, Anth.

div1.head: χιόνεος
div1.sense: snowy, snow-white, Bion., Anth.

div1.head: χιονίζω
div1.sense: to snow upon, cover with snow: impers., ἐχιόνιζε τὴν χώρην it was snowing over the country, Hdt.: εἰ ἐχιόνιζε if it was snowing, Hdt.

div1.head: χιονόβλητος
div1.sense: snow-beaten, Ar.

div1.head: χιονοθρέμμων
div1.sense: fostering snow, snow-clad, Eur.

div1.head: χιονόκτυπος
div1.sense: snow-beaten, Soph.

div1.head: χιονόχρως
div1.sense: with snow-white skin: snow-white, of a swan, Eur.

div1.head: χιονώδης
div1.sense: like snow, snowy, Eur.

div1.head: Χίος
div1.sense: Chios, in the Aegean, an island, famed for its wine, Od.: also the town of Chios, Hdt., Thuc.

div1.head: Χῖος
div1.sense: Chian, of or from Chios, X. ἀοιδός, i. e. Homer, Theocr.; Χῖος οἶνος Ar.; so Χῖος alone, Anth.
as Subst., Χῖοι, οἱ, the Chians, Hdt., Thuc.
ὁ Χῖος (sc. βόλος) , the worst throw on the dice, the side with the ace-dot being called Χῖος, the opp. side with the size-point being Κῷος:—for οὐ Χῖος ἀλλὰ Κεῖος, v. Κέως.

div1.head: χῖ
div1.sense: Χ, χ, χῖ, τό, indecl., twenty-second letter of Gr. alphabet: as numeral, χ 600, ʼχ 600, 000: but inInscrr., Χ, is the first letter of χίλιοι, αι, α, 1000.—Changes of χ, in the dialects:
Doric for θ, as ὄρνιχος for ὄρνιθος.
Ionic represented by κ, as δέκομαι κιθών for δέχομαι χιτών.

put before λ to strengthen the sound, as χλαῖνα for λαῖνα, χλιαρός for λιαρός. The Poets in some words treated χ as a double consonant, so that a short vowel before it becomes long, as in βρόχος, ἰᾱχή, ἰᾱχέω (qq. v.), φαιο_χίτων.

div1.head: χιτώνιον
div1.sense: properly a womanʼs frock or shift, Ar.;—also of men, Luc.

div1.head: χιτωνίσκος
div1.sense: a short frock, worn by men, Ar., Xen., etc.; of women, a shift, Dem.

div1.head: χιτών
div1.sense: the garment worn next the skin, a frock, Lat. tunica:
in early times, a manʼs frock, Hom.; sometimes with a girdle, and reaching to the feet (τερμιόεις) , Od.; of linen, Od.; over it was worn a mantle (φᾶρος, χλαῖνα) , which was laid aside in the house.

in later times we hear of two sorts of χιτών, the Ionian and the Dorian;—the Ionian like the Homeric, but worn by women, as well as men, Hdt.; disused by the men about the time of Pericles, Thuc.;—Dorian adopted at Athens when the Ionian was laid aside. The Dorian χιτών was also worn by Spartan women, being open at the side (σχιστός) , and fastened with περόναι, Hdt.—Over this χιτών was worn the ἱμάτιον.
of soldiers, a coat of mail, of leather covered with scales or rings, Il., Hdt.
the upper leather of a shoe, in pl., Xen.
metaph. any coat, case, or covering, λάϊνος χιτών (v. λάϊνος) ; τειχέων κιθῶνες, i. e. walls, Hdt.; of a serpentʼs skin, Eur.

div1.head: χιών
div1.sense: snow, Hom., etc.; νιφάδες χιόνος snow flakes, Il.; χιὼν πίπτουσα Hdt.; χιόνι κατανίφει Ar.
snow-water, ice-cold water, Eur.
div1.etym: From Root !χι, cf. χεῖμα, Lat. hiems.

div1.head: χλάδω
div1.sense: assumed as present of κέχλαδα to exult, a perf. form in Pind.; καλλίνικος κεχλᾱδώς, of a triumphal hymn, κεχλάδοντας ἥβαι, of young heroes.

div1.head: χλαῖνα
div1.sense: Lat. laena, a large square upper-garment, a cloak, mantle, Hom.; it was made of wool, and worn over the χιτών, thrown over the shoulders, fastened with a pin or brooch (περόνη) .— It is also called φᾶρος by Hom., and in later Greek ἱμάτιον, Latin pallium.

div1.head: χλαινόω
div1.sense: to cover with a cloak, to clothe, Anth.

div1.head: χλαίνωμα
div1.sense: clothing, χλ. λέοντος a lionʼs skin cloak, Anth.

div1.head: χλαμυδηφόρος
div1.sense: one who wears a χλαμύς, a horseman, cavalier, of the ephebi, Theocr.

div1.head: χλαμύδιον
div1.sense: Dim. of χλαμύς, Plut.
a shabby cloak, Plut.

div1.head: χλαμυδοειδής
div1.sense: like a χλαμύς, Strab.

div1.head: χλαμυδουργία
div1.sense: the making of χλαμύδες, the trade of a χλαμυδουργός, Xen.

div1.head: χλαμύς
div1.sense: a short mantle, worn by horsemen, Xen.; and by the Athen. ἔφηβοι, Anth.
generally, a military cloak, Plut.:—also the generalʼs cloak, Lat. paludamentum, Plut.

div1.head: χλανίδιον
div1.sense: mostly a womanʼs mantle, Hdt., Soph., Eur.

div1.head: χλανιδοποιία
div1.sense: the art of a χλανιδοποιός, Xen.

div1.head: χλανίσκιον
div1.sense: a cloaklet, Ar., Aeschin.: so χλανισκίδιον, ου, τό, Ar.

div1.head: χλανίς
div1.sense: an upper-garment of wool, a shawl, finer than the χλαῖνα, mostly worn by women, Hdt.; χλανίδα φορεῖν, as a mark of effeminacy, Dem.

div1.head: χλαρός
div1.sense: exultant, χλαρὸν γελᾶν Pind.

div1.head: χλευάζω
div1.sense: to joke, jest, scoff, jeer, Ar., Dem.:—so in Mid., Plut.
c. acc. to mock, scoff at, Dem.

div1.head: χλευασία
div1.sense: mockery, scoffing, Dem.

div1.head: χλευασμός
div1.sense: = χλευασία, Dem.
a joke, Plut.

div1.head: χλευαστής
div1.sense: a mocker, scoffer, Arist.

div1.head: χλεύη
div1.sense: a joke, jest, Hhymn.; χλεύην ποιεῖσθαί τινα to make a jest of one, Anth.

div1.head: χλῆδος
div1.sense: slime, mud, rubbish, Dem.

div1.head: χλιαίνω
div1.sense: to warm, Ar., Anth.
to heat with passion:—Pass. to be so heated, Anth.

div1.head: χλιαρός
div1.sense: warm, lukewarm, Lat. tepidus, Hdt., Ar.
of persons, lukewarm, NTest.

div1.head: χλιδαίνομαι
div1.sense: Pass. to be luxurious, revel, Xen.

div1.head: χλιδανός
div1.sense: luxurious, delicate, voluptuous, Aesch., Eur.

div1.head: χλιδάω
div1.sense: to be soft or delicate, χλιδῶσα μολπή Pind.:— to live delicately, to revel, luxuriate, τινί in a thing, Aesch.; χλ. ἐπί τινι to pride oneself upon a thing, Soph.

div1.head: χλιδή
div1.sense: delicacy, daintiness, luxury, effeminacy, Hdt., Aesch., Plat.
wantonness, insolence, arrogance, Aesch., Soph.
luxuries, fine raiment, costly ornaments, Lat. deliciae, Eur.;—so in pl., Eur.; καράτομοι χλιδαί luxuriant hair cut from the head, Soph.; παρθένιον χλιδάν a maidenʼs pride, Eur.

div1.head: χλίω
div1.sense: to be or become warm: hence to luxuriate, revel, ἐν τοῖσι σοῖς πόνοισι Aesch.

div1.head: χλοαυγής
div1.sense: with a greenish lustre, Luc.

div1.head: χλοεροτρόφος
div1.sense: producing green grass, Eur.

div1.head: χλοηκομέω
div1.sense: to be green as a young leaf, Anth.

div1.head: χλόη
div1.sense: the first shoot of plants in spring, the green blade of corn or grass, Hdt., Eur., etc.
the young verdure of trees, foliage, Eur.

div1.head: χλοηφόρος
div1.sense: bearing green grass or leaves, Eur.

div1.head: χλούνης
div1.sense: Epic epith. of the wild boar, of unknown sense and deriv., perh. for χλο-εύνης, couching in the greenwood, χλ. σῦς ἄγριος Il.; χλοῦναι σύες Hes.

div1.head: χλοῦνις
div1.sense: a word of unknown sense, perh. freshness, youthful vigour, Aesch.

div1.head: χλωρηΐς
div1.sense: pale-green, brown-green, of the nightingale, Od.

div1.head: χλωρόκομος
div1.sense: green-leaved, Eur.

div1.head: χλωρός
div1.sense: greenish-yellow (like young grass or leaves), pale-green, light-green, green, grassy, Od., Soph., Eur.; σίτου ἔτι χλωροῦ ὄντος Thuc.
yellow, of honey, Hom.; ἀμφὶ χλωρὰν ψάμαθον on the yellow sand, Soph.
generally, pale, pallid, bleached, χλωρὸς ὑπαὶ δείους Il.;—then, as an epith. of fear, χλωρὸν δέος Hom.:— yellow, pallid, of persons affected by the plague, Thuc.
without regard to colour, green, i. e. fresh, Od., Ar.
metaph. fresh, living, χλωρὸν αἷμα Soph., Eur.; χλωρὸν δάκρυ, like θαλερὸν δάκρυ, the fresh, bursting tear, Eur.; χλ. μέλεα fresh, young limbs, Theocr.

div1.head: χλωρότης
div1.sense: greenness, Plut.

div1.head: χναύω
div1.sense: properly = κνάω, to gnaw, nibble, Eur.

div1.head: χνοάζω
div1.sense: of youths, to get the first down on the chin: metaph., χνοάζων ἄρτι λευκανθὲς κάρα just sprinkling his hair with white (cf. Shakspeareʼs "sable silvered"), Soph.

div1.head: χνοάω
div1.sense: of youths, Theocr., Luc.: of the down on the cheeks, to appear, Anth.

div1.head: χνόη
div1.sense: the box of a wheel in which the axle turns, the nave, Lat. modiolus, Aesch., Soph.
metaph., χνόαι ποδῶν the joints on which the feet play, as the wheels on the axle, Aesch.

div1.head: χνόος
div1.sense: any light porous substance, ἁλὸς χνόος the foam that gathers at the edge of the sea, Od.; πωλικὸς χν. horseʼs foam, Anth.
the first down on the chin of youths, Lat. lanugo, Ar.: the bloom on fruit, Anth.

div1.head: χοανεύω
div1.sense: to cast into a mould (χοανός) , Ar.
to cast metal:—Pass., κεχωνευμένος Plut.

div1.head: χοάνη
div1.sense: a funnel, Lat. infundibulum, Plat.
= χόανος, Anth.

div1.head: χόανος
div1.sense: a melting-pot, from which the metal was run into the mould, Il., Hes.
the mould for casting metal in, Anth.

div1.head: χοή
div1.sense: a drink-offering, Lat. libatio, such especially as were made to the dead (λοιβή or σπονδή being that made to the gods), Od.; often in pl., Trag.
rarely of any other than funeral libations, Soph.

div1.head: χοήρης
div1.sense: fitted for the Pitcher-feast at Athens (v. χοῦς A. II), Eur.

div1.head: χοηφόρος
div1.sense: offering χοαί to the dead; Χοηφόροι, a Tragedy by Aesch., in which the Chorus pours libations to the shade of Agamemnon.

div1.head: χοϊκός
div1.sense: of earth or dust, NTest.

div1.head: χοινικίς
div1.sense: the circle of a crown, Dem.

div1.head: χοῖνιξ
div1.sense: a choenix, a dry measure, = four κοτύλαι or two sextarii, about a quart Engl., Hdt.; the choenix of corn was one manʼs daily allowance, Hdt.; hence, ὅς κεν ἐμῆς γε χοίνικος ἅπτηται i. e. whoever eats of my bread, Od.
a kind of shackle or stocks for fastening the legs in, Ar., Dem.

div1.head: χοιραδώδης
div1.sense: full of χοιράδες, rocky, Strab.

div1.head: χοιράς
div1.sense: of a hog, χ. πέτραι rocks (rising just above the sea) like a hogʼs back (cf. Virgilʼs dorsum immane maris), Pind., Anth.:—hence χοιράς as Subst., a sunken rock, Hdt., Aesch.; so, χ. Δηλία the Delian rock, the rocky isle of Delos, Aesch.
in pl. scrofulous swellings in the glands of the neck, Anth.

div1.head: χοίρειος
div1.sense: of a swine, Ar., Xen.; χοίρεα (sc. κρέα) pigʼs-flesh, Od.

div1.head: χοιρίνη
div1.sense: a small sea-muscle: its shell was used by the Athenian dicasts in voting, Ar.

div1.head: χοίρινος
div1.sense: of hogʼs skin, Luc.

div1.head: χοιρίον
div1.sense: a pigling, porker, Ar.

div1.head: χοιροκομεῖον
div1.sense: a pigsty, Ar.

div1.head: χοιροκτόνος
div1.sense: χοιροκτόνοι καθαρμοί purification by the sacrifice of swine, Aesch.

div1.head: χοιροπώλης
div1.sense: a pig-jobber, Ar.

div1.head: χοῖρος
div1.sense: a young pig, porker, Od., etc.

div1.head: Χολαργεύς
div1.sense: a man of the deme Χόλαργος, Ar.

div1.head: χολάς
div1.sense: commonly in pl. χολάδες, the bowels, intestines, guts, Il.; made into harp-strings, Anth.

div1.head: χολάω
div1.sense: to be full of black bile, to be melancholy mad, Ar.
= χολόομαι, to be angry, Mosch.; so in Pass., Theogn.

div1.head: χολή
div1.sense: gall, bile, Aesch., Eur., Thuc., etc.
pl. χολαί, the gall-bladder, Soph.; called δοχαὶ χολῆς in Eur.;—so in sg., Aesch.
metaph., like χόλος, Lat. bilis, bile, gall, i. e. bitter anger, wrath, Aesch., Ar., etc.; πάνυ ἐστί μοι χολή stirs my bile, makes me sick, Ar.; χολὴν κινεῖν τινι Ar.

div1.head: χόλιξ
div1.sense: mostly in pl. χόλικες, like χολάδες, the guts or bowels of oxen, Ar.; in sg., Ar.

div1.head: χόλιος
div1.sense: raging, angry, Anth.

div1.head: Χολλείδης
div1.sense: a man of the deme Cholleidae, Ar.

div1.head: χόλος
div1.sense: like χόλη, gall, bile, Il.

generally metaph. bile, gall, bitter anger, wrath, Hom., Hdt., Attic; χόλος ἔδυ τινά Il.; χόλος ἔμπεσε θυμῷ Il.; χόλον πέσσειν, καταπέσσειν (v. sub. vocc.); χ. σβέσσαι παῦσαι Il.; χόλου παύεσθαι Hes.:—c. gen. objecti, anger towards or because of another, Il.; c. gen. rei, anger for, because of a thing, Soph.
an object of anger, Anth.

div1.head: χολόω
div1.sense: to make angry, provoke, anger, Hom., Soph.
Mid. and Pass. to be angered or provoked to anger, Hom.; βασιλῆι χολωθείς angry with the king, Il.; c. gen., κεχολωμένος τινός angry because of a person or thing, Hom.

div1.head: χολώδης
div1.sense: like bile or gall, bilious, Plat.
bilious, angry, Luc.

div1.head: χολωτός
div1.sense: angry, wrathful, Hom.

div1.head: χονδρός
div1.sense: granular, coarse, χονδροὶ ἅλες rock-salt, Ar.

div1.head: χόνδρος
div1.sense: a grain or lump of salt, ἁλὸς τρύφεα κατὰ χόνδρους μεγάλους pieces of salt in large grains, Hdt.:— χόνδρος absol. for salt, Anth.
in pl. groats of wheat or spelt: gruel made therefrom, Ar.

div1.head: χοραύλης
div1.sense: one who accompanies a chorus on the flute, Anth., Plut.

div1.head: χόρδευμα
div1.sense: a sausage or black-pudding, Ar.

div1.head: χορδεύω
div1.sense: to make into sausages: metaph., χ. τὰ πράγματα to make mince-meat of state-affairs, Ar.

div1.head: χορδή
div1.sense: gut-string, the string of a lyre, Lat. chorda, Od., Eur.
tripe, Batr.: also = χόρδευμα, Ar.

div1.head: χορεία
div1.sense: a dance, esp. the choral or round dance with its music, Eur., Ar.
a dance tune, Ar.

div1.head: χόρευμα
div1.sense: a choral dance, Eur.

div1.head: χορευτέος
div1.sense: one must dance, Eur.

div1.head: χορευτής
div1.sense: a choral dancer, Pind., Ar.: —metaph., θεοῦ χ. the follower of a god, Plat.

div1.head: χορευτικός
div1.sense: of or for the dance, Luc. From

div1.head: χορεύω
div1.sense: to dance a round or choral dance, Soph., etc.; esp. of the Bacchic chorus, Eur.:— to take part in the chorus, regarded as a matter of religion, Soph.: to be one of a chorus, Ar.: —c. dat. pers. to dance to him, in his honour, Eur.
generally, to dance, esp. from joy, Soph., Eur.
metaph. to practise a thing, be versed in it, Plat.

c. acc. cogn., φροίμιον χορεύσομαι I will dance a prelude (to festivities), Aesch.; χ. γάμους to celebrate them, Eur.; ὄργια Μουσῶν Ar.:—Mid., χορεύεσθαι δίνας to ply the eddying dance, Eur.:—Pass., κεχόρευται ἡμῖν (sings the Chorus) our part is played, Ar.
trans. to celebrate in choral dance, Ἴακχον Soph.:—Pass. to be celebrated in choral dance, Ar.
Causal, to set one a dancing, to rouse, wake to the dance, τινά Eur.; so, πόδα χορεύειν Anth.

div1.head: χορηγεῖον
div1.sense: the place in which a chorus was trained, their dancing-school, Dem.
in pl. χορηγεῖα or χορήγια, ων, τά, supplies for an army, Lat. commeatus, Polyb.; cf. χορηγία II. 2.

div1.head: χορηγέω
div1.sense: to lead a chorus, Plat.: metaph. to take the lead in a matter, c. gen., τούτου τοῦ λόγου Plat.

in Attic of the χορηγός, to defray the cost of bringing out a chorus at the public feasts, to act as choragus, Oratt.; c. dat., χ. χορῶι Plat.; χ. ἀνδράσι ἐς Διονύσια Lys.; χ. κωμωιδοῖς Lys.; also with the feast in acc., χορ. Λήναια Ar.; Διονύσια Dem.:—Pass. to have choragi found for one, χορηγοῦσιν μὲν οἱ πλούσιοι, χορηγεῖται δὲ ὁ δῆμος Xen.
metaph. to minister to, χ. ταῖς σεαυτοῦ ἡδοναῖς Aeschin.
metaph. also,
c. acc. pers. to furnish abundantly with a thing, esp. with supplies for war, Polyb.:—Pass. to be well supplied, Arist.
c. acc. rei, to supply, furnish, Dem.

div1.head: χορηγία
div1.sense: the office of a χορηγός at Athens, the defraying of the cost of the public choruses, being the chief of the λειτουργίαι, Thuc., etc.
means for providing χοροί· abundance of means, fortune, Arist.
metaph. supplies for war, Polyb.

div1.head: χορηγικός
div1.sense: of or for a χορηγός, χ. ἀγῶνες rivalry in bringing out choruses, Xen.

div1.head: χορηγός
div1.sense: a chorus leader, Plat.:— the leader of a train or band, Soph., Eur.
at Athens, one who defrayed the costs for bringing out a chorus, Dem., Aeschin.
one who supplies the costs for any purposes, Dem., Aeschin.

div1.head: χορικός
div1.sense: of or for a choral dance, choral, Plat., Arist.

div1.head: χόριον
div1.sense: the membrane that encloses the fetus, the afterbirth, Lat. secundae: pl. χόρια, ων, τά, a dish made by stuffing it with honey and milk, a kind of haggis, Ar.: proverb., χαλεπὸν χορίω (Doric gen.) κύνα γεῦσαι "donʼt let a dog taste blood, " Theocr. (cf. Horace, canis a corio nunquam absterrebitur uncto).

div1.head: χοροδιδασκαλία
div1.sense: the office of χοροδιδάσκαλος, Plat.

div1.head: χοροδιδασκαλικός
div1.sense: of or for the χοροδιδάσκαλος: ἡ -κή (sc. τέχνη) , = χοροδιδασκαλία, Plat.

div1.head: χοροδιδάσκαλος
div1.sense: the person who trained the chorus to dance and sing, the chorus-master, Ar., Dem.:— this was originally the Poet himself, v. διδάσκω II.

div1.head: χοροήθης
div1.sense: accustomed to the choral dance, Hhymn.

div1.head: χοροιθαλής
div1.sense: flourishing in the dance, Anth.

div1.head: χοροιμανία
div1.sense: furious dancing, Anth.

div1.head: χοροιτυπία
div1.sense: choral dancing, Il., Anth.

div1.head: χοροιτύπος
div1.sense: beating the ground in the dance, dancing, Pind.

div1.head: χοροίτυπος
div1.sense: proparox. χοροίτυπος, ον, pass. played to the choral dance, Hhymn.

div1.head: χορόνδε
div1.sense: to the festive dance, Il.

div1.head: χοροπαίκτης
div1.sense: dancing merrily, Anth.

div1.head: χοροποιός
div1.sense: instituting or arranging a chorus, Xen.
leading the dance, Soph., Eur.

div1.head: χορός
div1.sense: a round dance, used at banquets and festive occasions, Hom., Hes.:—at Athens, the χορὸς κύκλιος performed round the altar of Dionysus, Hdt., Eur., etc.

from the Dionysiac Chorus arose the Attic Drama, which consisted at first of tales inserted in the intervals of the Dance (ἐπεισόδια) , recited by a single actor: this dramatic chorus was either τραγικός consisting usually of 15 persons, or κωμικός of 24. When a Poet wished to bring out a piece, he asked a Chorus from the Archon, and the expenses, being great, were defrayed by some rich citizen (the χορηγός) : it was furnished by the Tribe and trained originally by the Poet himself (hence called χοροδιδάσκαλος) .
a chorus, choir, i. e. a band of dancers and singers, Hhymn., Pind.
generally, a choir or troop, τέκνων Eur.; also of things, χ. σκευῶν a row of dishes, Xen.; χ. ὀδόντων a row of teeth, whence the joke of οἱ πρόσθιοι χοροί, for the front teeth, Ar.
a place for dancing, λείηναν χορόν Od., etc.

div1.head: χοροστασία
div1.sense: institution of choruses: generally, a chorus, dance, Anth.

div1.head: χορτάζω
div1.sense: to feed, fatten cattle, Hes., Ar.:—Pass. to eat their fill, Plat.

div1.head: χορτασία
div1.sense: a being fed, feasting, Anth.

div1.head: χόρτασμα
div1.sense: fodder, forage: food for men, NTest.

div1.head: χόρτος
div1.sense: an inclosed place, a feeding-place, αὐλῆς ἐν χόρτῳ Il.
generally, any feeding-ground, in pl. χόρτοι λέοντος Pind.; χόρτοι εὔδενδροι Eur.
food, fodder, provender, esp. for cattle, Hes., etc.; grass, NTest.; χόρτος κοῦφος hay, Xen.: opp. to σῖτος (food for man), Hdt., Xen.: food generally, Eur., Anth.

div1.head: χοῦς
div1.sense: Lat. congius, a liquid measure = 12 κοτύλαι, nearly 3 quarts, Ar., etc.
proverb. of attempts to measure the immeasurable, οἱ τῆς θαλάττης λεγόμενοι χόες Plat.
Χόες, οἱ, the Pitcher-feast, the second day of the Anthesteria at Athens, Ar., Dem.

div1.head: χοῦς2
div1.sense: earth thrown down or heaped up, like χῶμα, Hdt.
= κονιορτός, dust, NTest.

div1.head: χόω
div1.sense: to throw or heap up, of earth, χοῦσι χῶμα μέγα Hdt.; χώματα χῶν πρὸς τὰ τείχεα throwing up banks against . . , Hdt.; χῶμα ἔχουν πρὸς τὴν πόλιν Thuc.; νῆσον χώσας σποδῶι having formed an island with heaped up ashes, Hdt.
to block up by throwing earth in, χ. τοὺς λιμένας Dem., Aeschin.: —Pass. of bays in the sea, to be silted up, Hdt.; of cities, to be raised on mounds, Hdt.
to cover with earth, to bury, χῶσαί τινα τάφωι Eur.:—Pass. to be covered with a heap of earth, i. e. to have a sepulchral mound raised over one, Anth.

div1.head: χραίνω
div1.sense: to touch slightly, ὀλιγάκις ἄστυ χραίνων, i. e. keeping aloof from it, Eur.
to stain, spot, defile, Aesch.;— esp. of moral pollution, Soph., Eur.:—Mid., χεῖρα χραίνεσθαι φόνωι Soph.:—Pass. to be defiled, Soph.

div1.head: χραισμέω
div1.sense: to ward off from one, c. acc. rei et dat. pers., ὄλεθρόν τινι χρ. Il.
c. dat. pers. only, to defend any one, help, aid, succour, avail him, Il.; χραισμεῖν τι to assist, avail at all, Il.

div1.head: χράομαι
div1.sense: from the sense of consulting or using an oracle (v. χράω3) comes the common sense to use, Lat. uti, Il., etc.; φρεσὶ κέχρητʼ ἀγαθῆισι he was endowed with a good heart, Od.: c. dat., χρῆσθαι ἀργυρίωι to have money to use for a purpose, use it thereon, Plat.; χρ. ναυτιλίηισι, θαλάσσηι Hdt., Thuc.
in various relations, ὀργῆι or θυμῶι χρῆσθαι to indulge oneʼs anger, give vent to it, Hdt.

of external things, to experience, suffer, be subject to, νιφετῶι Hdt.; χρ. γαληνείαι to have fair weather, Eur.; ὁμολογίαι χπ. to come to an agreement, Hdt.; ζυγῶι χρ. δουλίωι to become a slave, Aesch.; συμφορῆι, συντυχίηι, εὐτυχίηι χρ., Lat. uti fortuna mala, prospera, Hdt., etc.; νόμοις χρ. to live under laws, Eur.; χρ. ἀνομίαι Xen., etc.:—in many cases, χρῆσθαι merely paraphrases the Verb cognate to its dat., μόρωι χρ. i. e. to die, Hdt.; ὠνῆι καὶ πράσει χρ. ὠνεῖσθαι καὶ πιπράσκειν, to buy and sell, Hdt.; χρ. δρασμῶι διδράσκειν, Aeschin.; χρ. φωνῆι φωνεῖν, διαβολῆι χρ. διαβάλλεσθαι etc., Plat.
